EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad upper level ridge over the Desert Southwest led to excessive heat conditions across portions of southeast California.
A broad upper level ridge over the Desert Southwest led to excessive heat conditions across portions of southeast California.

A broad upper level ridge over the Desert Southwest led to continued above normal temperatures along with excessive heat conditions for the middle part of September. Temperatures most afternoons during this time in Phoenix topped out around 108-109 degrees. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 10 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time. One of these fatalities included a person who died while hiking in Scottsdale. According to local media reports, a couple from Rhode Island started hiking around noon on the 12th at Brown's Ranch Trailhead in Scottsdale. After splitting up during the hike, the wife never returned to their meeting location. Local authorities responded and discovered that the wife had succumbed to the heat.

A large ridge of high pressure dominated the western United States for several days. This resulted in scorching heat and dry weather across the lower elevations of eastern Utah. Conditions were exceptionally dry which translated to single digit humidity at the surface. Record breaking high temperatures occurred through the period with overnight lows only dropping into the low to mid to upper 60s and 70s in the valleys.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures of 101 to 106 degrees were reported by various automated weather stations and observers each day through the period. Additionally, overnight lows ranged from 78 to 79 degrees on the morning of the 17th and 18th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures of 101 to 107 degrees were reported by various automated weather stations each day through the period. Additionally, overnight lows ranged from 74 to 76 degrees on the morning of the 17th and 18th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over California resulted in very hot daytime temperatures and warm overnight low temperatures across interior Northern California. High to very high heat risk impacted the region. Two daily high temperature records were broken. During the event, cooling centers were made available to the public across interior Northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake Shasta Dam area saw high temperatures reach 110 to 114 degrees during the event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over California resulted in very hot daytime temperatures and warm overnight low temperatures across interior Northern California. High to very high heat risk impacted the region. Two daily high temperature records were broken. During the event, cooling centers were made available to the public across interior Northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sacramento region saw high temperatures reach 105 degrees. On the 14th, downtown Sacramento recorded a high temperature of 103 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced west and south of Tucson September 11 through 14. The hottest two days were the 12th and 13th when high temperatures fell just shy of records across much of Pima County and topped out between 104 and 109 degrees. During the four day period, the Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for seven individuals found in the desert, one at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, five on the Tohono O'odham Nation, and one in Santa Cruz County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 3 to 5 degrees above normal, around 105 degrees, were experienced across the western and central Pima County causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached on September 14. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two males found in the desert, one on the eastern edge of the Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument and another on the Tohono O'odham Nation northwest of Kohatk.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced west and south of Tucson September 11 through 14. During the four day period, the Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for seven individuals found in the desert, one at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, five on the Tohono O'odham Nation, and one in Santa Cruz County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced west and south of Tucson September 11 through 14. The hottest two days were the 12th and 13th when high temperatures fell just shy of records across much of Pima County and topped out between 104 and 109 degrees. During the four day period, the Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for seven individuals found in the desert, one at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, five on the Tohono O'odham Nation, and one in Santa Cruz County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot high temperatures of 105 to 109 degrees, or 5 to 10 degrees above normal, occurred in the lower deserts of western Pima County and the Tohono O'odham Nation September 12-13, and caused the High Heat Risk category to be reached. While temperatures fell just shy of records, the Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three persons found in the desert on the Tohono O'odham Nation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably hot temperatures occurred in advance of a slow moving cold front. High temperatures across portions of west-central and Downeast Maine ranged from around 90 to the mid 90s...with dewpoints of around 70 to the lower 70s. Apparent temperatures generally ranged from the upper 90s to around 105.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Apparent temperatures ranged from the upper 90s to around 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures of 95 to 100 degrees in the San Pedro River Valley of Cochise County were experienced on August 6. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one male found in the desert.

The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one male found near Palominas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures just above 100 degrees in the Tucson Metro Area were experienced on August 29. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one male found in the city.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures 5 degrees above normal, just over 100 degrees, occurred in the Tucson Metro Area causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached on August 29. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one male found on the northwest side of Tucson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures around 100 degrees in southern Cochise County were experienced on July 6. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two males found in the desert.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures 5 to 10 degrees above normal near 100 degrees, occurred in southern Cochise County causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached on July 10. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one male found in the desert near Palominas and another in the Leslie Canyon area.

CZ_NAME: UPPER SANTA CRUZ RIVER AND ALTAR VALLEYS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced west and south of Tucson September 11 through 14. The hottest two days were the 12th and 13th when high temperatures fell just shy of records across much of Pima County and topped out between 104 and 109 degrees. During the four day period, the Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for seven individuals found in the desert, one at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, five on the Tohono O'odham Nation, and one in Santa Cruz County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 4 to 6 degrees above normal, in the upper 90s, were experienced in the lower elevations of Santa Cruz County causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached on September 12. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one male found in the desert near Amado.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced west and south of Tucson September 11 through 14. The hottest two days were the 12th and 13th when high temperatures fell just shy of records across much of Pima County and topped out between 104 and 109 degrees. During the four day period, the Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for seven individuals found in the desert, one at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, five on the Tohono O'odham Nation, and one in Santa Cruz County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot high temperatures of 105 to 109 degrees, or 5 to 10 degrees above normal, occurred in the lower deserts of western Pima County and the Tohono O'odham Nation September 12-13, and caused the High Heat Risk category to be reached. While temperatures fell just shy of records, the Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three persons found in the desert on the Tohono O'odham Nation, one female north of San Simon on the 12th, another female southwest of Vamori and one male west of Cowlic on the 13th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Excessive heat occurred over southern portions of the Coastal Bend and Brush Country during the afternoon of the 21st. Heat index values ranged from 115 to 120 degrees across this area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive heat occurred over the area during the afternoon of the 21st. Heat index values ranged from 115 to 120 degrees with temperatures in the upper 90s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level high pressure parked over the region resulting in a period of unseasonably hot weather across Northeast Mississippi. High temperatures combined with high humidity to produce afternoon heat index values of 105 degrees or higher on August 1, 2021.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105 to 110 degrees in the afternoon and early evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level high pressure parked over the region resulting in a period of unseasonably hot weather across Northeast Mississippi. High temperatures combined with high humidity to produce afternoon heat index values of 105 degrees or higher on August 1, 2021.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105 to 110 degrees in the afternoon and early evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level high pressure re-strengthened over the Mid-South in late August resulting in hot and humid conditions. Afternoon heat index values greater than 105 degrees were widespread across the Mid-South.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105 to 110 degrees in the afternoon and early evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large ridge of high pressure dominated the western United States for several days. This resulted in scorching heat and dry weather across the lower elevations of western Colorado. Conditions were exceptionally dry which translated to single digit humidity at the surface. Record breaking high temperatures occurred through the period with overnight lows only dropping into the low to mid to upper 60s and 70s in the valleys.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures of 100 to 107 degrees were reported by various automated weather stations each day through the period. Additionally, overnight lows ranged from 70 to 73 degrees on the morning of the 8th and 9th. The Grand Junction Regional Airport set a new all-time record high on July 9th with a high of 107 degrees, breaking the old all-time record of 106 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large ridge of high pressure dominated the western United States for several days. This resulted in scorching heat and dry weather across the lower elevations of eastern Utah. Conditions were exceptionally dry which translated to single digit humidity at the surface. Record breaking high temperatures occurred through the period with overnight lows only dropping into the low to mid to upper 60s and 70s in the valleys.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures of 98 to 102 degrees were reported by various automated weather stations each day through the period. Additionally, overnight lows ranged from 60 to 69 degrees on the morning of the 17th and 18th.

This resulted in scorching heat and dry weather across the lower elevations of west-central Colorado. Conditions were exceptionally dry which translated to single digit humidity at the surface. Record breaking high temperatures occurred through the period with overnight lows only dropping into the low to mid to upper 60s and 70s in the Grand Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures of 102 to 105 degrees were reported by various automated weather stations each day through the period. Additionally, overnight lows ranged from 68 to 75 degrees on the morning of the 17th and 18th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A multi-day excessive heat event occurred across much of the mid-Atlantic from August 11-13, 2021. Temperatures in the mid to upper 90s combined with dew point values near 70 caused widespread heat index values near to above 105F on both August 11 and 12, and locally into the 13th before a cold front brought relief.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105F on August 11 and 12, and locally on the 13th. Some 110F values occurred on the 11th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A multi-day excessive heat event occurred across much of the mid-Atlantic from August 11-13, 2021. Temperatures in the mid to upper 90s combined with dew point values near 70 caused widespread heat index values near to above 105F on both August 11 and 12, and locally into the 13th before a cold front brought relief.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105F on August 11 and 12.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A historic heat wave affected the Pacific Northwest during this interval.  It was caused by a strong upper level ridge that created dry and stable conditions over the area with strong subsidence.  Many daily, monthly, and all-time high temperature records were set over southwest and south central Oregon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On 06/26/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 44 to 50 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 92 to 94 degrees. On 06/27/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 50 to 57 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 96 to 101 degrees. On 06/28/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 51 to 60 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 100 to 103 degrees. On 06/29/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 50 to 54 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 100 to 104 degrees. On 06/30/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 46 to 51 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 94 to 101 degrees.  Klamath Falls set a high temperature record for the month of June with 101 degrees on 06/27, the old record was 96 degrees, set in 2015.  This record was broken the very next day, 6/28, when a high temperature of 103 degrees was recorded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A historic heat wave affected the Pacific Northwest during this interval.  It was caused by a strong upper level ridge that created dry and stable conditions over the area with strong subsidence.  Many daily, monthly, and all-time high temperature records were set over southwest and south central Oregon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On 06/26/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 54 to 68 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 92 to 111 degrees. On 06/27/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 61 to 72 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 100 to 113 degrees. On 06/28/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 66 to 76 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 94 to 108 degrees. On 06/29/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 55 to 65 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 87 to 101 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The strong upper ridge which built inland into California during the Memorial Day holiday weekend remained in place over the region on June 1 and June 2 resulting in temperatures approaching record levels across the San Joaquin Valley, the West Side Hills and the southern Sierra foothills on June 1 and 2. Several stations across these areas had maximum temperatures exceeding the century mark on June 1 and June 2 prompting the continuation of Excessive Heat Warnings and the opening of cooling centers due to this event taking place early in the season. The near record heat heat continued in the Bakersfield area on June 3 and several stations in the Kern County Deserts had highs near 110 on June 2, June 3 and June 4. By June 5, the ridge had shifted east of the area allowing for daytime temperatures to cool slightly.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 103 and 107 degrees on June 1 and June 2.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The strong upper ridge which built inland into California during the Memorial Day holiday weekend remained in place over the region on June 1 and June 2 resulting in temperatures approaching record levels across the San Joaquin Valley, the West Side Hills and the southern Sierra foothills on June 1 and 2. Several stations across these areas had maximum temperatures exceeding the century mark on June 1 and June 2 prompting the continuation of Excessive Heat Warnings and the opening of cooling centers due to this event taking place early in the season. The near record heat heat continued in the Bakersfield area on June 3 and several stations in the Kern County Deserts had highs near 110 on June 2, June 3 and June 4. By June 5, the ridge had shifted east of the area allowing for daytime temperatures to cool slightly.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 107 and 112 degrees between June 2 and June 4.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lifting warm front across the region brought a hot and humid air mass into the region, leading to maximum heat indices reaching 95 to 98 degrees across some valley locations of eastern New York.||An approaching cold front from the west led to numerous showers and thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening hours. Some of these storms became severe with several reports of downed trees and power lines. A couple trees fell onto homes with another falling onto a camper trailer. No injuries were reported. A funnel cloud was spotted by an observer in Warren County looking northward toward Lake George. A lightning strike hit a structure near Galway, causing a fire. Sporadic power outages occurred as a result of these storms with more than 1,000 National Grid customers without power in Washington County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper ridge which was centered over the four corners area built westward and strengthened over central California between June 15 and June 18 resulting in dangerously hot daytime temperatures becoming prevalent over the Kern County Deserts by June 15 and over the Lake Isabella and Tehachapi areas by June 17.  The heat surged into the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and Sierra foothills by June 19 as daytime highs were 110 Degrees F or higher at several locations. Temperatures cooled slightly on June 20 and more significantly on June 21 and 22 as the ridge shifted to the east of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 106 and 112 degrees on June 15, 18 and 20 and between 110 and 116 degrees on June 16, 17 and 19.

A hot and humid airmass developed over eastern New York on the 27th and persisted through the 30th. Heat indices of 95 to 105 degrees were common, with the highest values on the 28th and 29th. The high reached the 90s for all four days at Poughkeepsie, and three days at Albany and Glens Falls.

A historic heat wave affected the Pacific Northwest during this interval.  It was caused by a strong upper level ridge that created dry and stable conditions over the area with strong subsidence.  Many daily, monthly, and all-time high temperature records were set over southwest and south central Oregon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On 06/26/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 51 to 59 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 91 to 98 degrees. On 06/27/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 49 to 70 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 94 to 103 degrees. On 06/28/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 57 to 66 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 95 to 105 degrees. On 06/29/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 51 to 70 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 91 to 107 degrees. On 06/30/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 55 to 62 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 93 to 101 degrees.

CZ_NAME: NORTHEAST SISKIYOU AND NORTHWEST MODOC COUNTIES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A historic heat wave affected the Pacific Northwest during this interval.  It was caused by a strong upper level ridge that created dry and stable conditions over the area with strong subsidence.  Many daily, monthly, and all-time high temperature records were set over northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tulelake was the only station from this zone that reported observations through this event. On 06/26/21, the low temperature was 51 degrees and the high temperature was 93 degrees. On 06/27/21, the low temperature was 54 degrees and the high temperature was 91 degrees. On 06/28/21, the low temperature was 61 degrees and the high temperature was 103 degrees. On 06/29/21, the low temperature was 55 degrees and the high temperature was 103 degrees. On 06/30/21, the low temperature was 52 degrees and the high temperature was 99 degrees. Lava Beds National Monument reported sporadically through this event.  They reported a low temperature of 61 degrees on 07/26/21, a high temperature of 98 degrees on 06/29/21, and a low temperature of 61 degrees on 06/30/21.

CZ_NAME: SANTA CLARA VALLEY INCLUDING SAN JOSE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure over the Four Corners brought a hot and dry air mass to the Central Coast and Bay Area in mid June. Hot daytime temperatures for multiple days in the triple digits resulted in record breaking heat for the interior portion of the region. Higher elevation areas reported daytime highs in the 100s with overnight lows in the 70s and 80s. Several sites broke daily record highs on June 17th. The heat lasted into the start of that coming weekend and resulted in one fatality in San Jose. Additionally, persistent hot/dry conditions along with near record dry fuels allowed for the development of the Willow Fire in Monterey County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County medical examiner reported that a man died in San Jose due to hyperthermia after collapsing due to heat exhaustion. The man collapse on the 17th and later died on the 19th. Exact time unknown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid airmass developed on June 28th and persisted through June 30th. Heat index values between 100F to 105F were recorded over northwestern Connecticut.
A hot and humid airmass developed on June 28th and persisted through June 30th. Heat index values between 100F to 105F were recorded over northwestern Connecticut.
A hot and humid airmass developed over southern Vermont on June 28th and persisted through June 30th. Max heat indices ranged between 100F to 106F in Brattleboro, VT.

A strong ridge parked over the northern Rockies and brought very hot temperatures to much of western and central Wyoming. All of the lower elevations saw high temperatures 90 degrees or above with many high temperatures over 100 in the lower elevations East of the Continental Divide. The Greybull and Johnson County airports tied their all time record highs of 108 and 104 degrees respectively, on June 15th. The high of 106 at the Worland airport on June 15th missed the all time record high by 1 degree.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Well above normal temperatures occurred in Yellowstone Park. The highest temperature was 91 degrees at Mammoth Hot Springs on June 15th.

A multi-day excessive heat event occurred across much of the mid-Atlantic near the end of June 2021. High temperatures in the mid to locally upper 90s combined with dew points in the upper 60s to near 70 caused heat index values to reach 105 to 110 over much of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105F on both June 29 and 30.

CZ_NAME: SANTA CLARA VALLEY INCLUDING SAN JOSE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure over the Four Corners brought a hot and dry air mass to the Central Coast and Bay Area in mid June. Hot daytime temperatures for multiple days in the triple digits resulted in record breaking heat for the interior portion of the region. Higher elevation areas reported daytime highs in the 100s with overnight lows in the 70s and 80s. Several sites broke daily record highs on June 17th. The heat lasted into the start of that coming weekend and resulted in one fatality in San Jose. Additionally, persistent hot/dry conditions along with near record dry fuels allowed for the development of the Willow Fire in Monterey County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daily record broken in Gilroy of 106 previously 105 in 1961.

CZ_NAME: WESTERN SAN JOAQUIN VALLEY IN KERN COUNTY
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper ridge which was centered over the four corners area built westward and strengthened over central California between June 15 and June 18 resulting in dangerously hot daytime temperatures becoming prevalent over the Kern County Deserts by June 15 and over the Lake Isabella and Tehachapi areas by June 17.  The heat surged into the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and Sierra foothills by June 19 as daytime highs were 110 Degrees F or higher at several locations. Temperatures cooled slightly on June 20 and more significantly on June 21 and 22 as the ridge shifted to the east of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 108 and 113 degrees on June 18 and 19 and between 106 and 111 degrees on June 20.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge parked over the northern Rockies and brought very hot temperatures to much of western and central Wyoming. All of the lower elevations saw high temperatures 90 degrees or above with many high temperatures over 100 in the lower elevations East of the Continental Divide. The Greybull and Johnson County airports tied their all time record highs of 108 and 104 degrees respectively, on June 15th. The high of 106 at the Worland airport on June 15th missed the all time record high by 1 degree.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A high temperature of 102 degrees was record in downtown Riverton, Wyoming on the 15th on June. The ASOS at the Riverton airport had a high temperature of 100 on the same day.

A multi-day excessive heat event occurred across much of the mid-Atlantic near the end of June 2021. High temperatures in the mid to locally upper 90s combined with dew points in the upper 60s to near 70 caused heat index values to reach 105 to 110 over much of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105F on June 30.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A historic heat wave affected the Pacific Northwest during this interval.  It was caused by a strong upper level ridge that created dry and stable conditions over the area with strong subsidence.  Many daily, monthly, and all-time high temperature records were set over northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On 06/28/21, the only high temperature reported from this zone was 104 degrees at Fort Jones. On 06/30/21, the only report again came from Fort Jones, with a low of 59 degrees and a high of 103 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A historic heat wave affected the Pacific Northwest during this interval.  It was caused by a strong upper level ridge that created dry and stable conditions over the area with strong subsidence.  Many daily, monthly, and all-time high temperature records were set over northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Alturas (AAT) was the only station from this zone that reported observations. On 06/26/21, the low temperature was 48 degrees and the high temperature was 96 degrees. On 06/27/21, the low temperature was 56 degrees and the high temperature was 100 degrees. On 06/28/21, the low temperature was 59 degrees and the high temperature was 105 degrees. On 06/29/21, the low temperature was 53 degrees and the high temperature was 103 degrees. On 06/30/21, the low temperature was 53 degrees and the high temperature was 98 degrees. On 06/28/21, the high temperature reading of 105 in Alturas set a high temperature record for the month of June. The old record was 102 degrees on 06/25/1961.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure anchored from the Four Corners Region north through the Plains into the Southern Canadian provinces, expanded east into the Lower Mississippi Valley on June 14th. Meanwhile, a weak surface trough over portions of East Texas and North Louisiana slowly drifted south during the day, but enhanced compressional warming and moisture pooling over these areas. This contributed in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid and upper 90s, with the oppressively high humidity resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees.

The strong upper ridge which built inland into California during the Memorial Day holiday weekend remained in place over the region on June 1 and June 2 resulting in temperatures approaching record levels across the San Joaquin Valley, the West Side Hills and the southern Sierra foothills on June 1 and 2. Several stations across these areas had maximum temperatures exceeding the century mark on June 1 and June 2 prompting the continuation of Excessive Heat Warnings and the opening of cooling centers due to this event taking place early in the season. The near record heat heat continued in the Bakersfield area on June 3 and several stations in the Kern County Deserts had highs near 110 on June 2, June 3 and June 4. By June 5, the ridge had shifted east of the area allowing for daytime temperatures to cool slightly.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 103 and 107 degrees on June 1 and between 100 and 105 degrees on June 2.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strengthening ridge along with an offshore flow pattern brought a short lived return of dangerous heat the area as much of the San Joaquin Valley exceeded 105 F on June 27 while portions of the Kern County Deserts exceeded 110 F. Increased clouds helped lower temperatures below dangerous level in the San Joaquin Valley on June 28, but high temperatures across the Kern County Deserts were 1-3 Degrees warmer than the previous day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 106 and 111 degrees on June 27 and between 108 and 113 degrees on June 28.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A historic heat wave affected the Pacific Northwest during this interval.  It was caused by a strong upper level ridge that created dry and stable conditions over the area with strong subsidence.  Many daily, monthly, and all-time high temperature records were set over northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On 06/26/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 57 to 61 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 103 to 104 degrees. On 06/27/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 63 to 68 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 107 to 110 degrees.  On 06/28/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 65 to 68 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 106 to 110 degrees.  On 06/29/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 61 to 64 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 103 to 105 degrees.  On 06/30/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone were all 61 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 101 to 103 degrees. On 6/27/21, Montague tied their all-time high temperatures record of 109 degrees, the other 109 degree reading occurred on 7/11/2002. This also broke the high temperature record for the month of June; the old record was 104 set on 06/20/2021.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A historic heat wave affected the Pacific Northwest during this interval.  It was caused by a strong upper level ridge that created dry and stable conditions over the area with strong subsidence.  Many daily, monthly, and all-time high temperature records were set over southwest and south central Oregon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On 06/26/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 52 to 64 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 96 to 104 degrees. On 06/27/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 53 to 70 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 103 to 113 degrees. On 06/28/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 57 to 75 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 108 to 115 degrees. On 06/29/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 55 to 68 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 97 to 109 degrees. Medford set a record high temperature for the month of June with 113 degrees on 06/27/21, breaking the old record of 104, set in 2015.  This record was broken the following day, 06/28, when Medford recorded a high of 115 degrees. This reading tied the all-time high temperature record, first set on 07/20/1946.

By June 5, the ridge had shifted east of the area allowing for daytime temperatures to cool slightly.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 103 and 107 degrees on June 1 and between 100 and 105 degrees on June 2.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strengthening ridge along with an offshore flow pattern brought a short lived return of dangerous heat the area as much of the San Joaquin Valley exceeded 105 F on June 27 while portions of the Kern County Deserts exceeded 110 F. Increased clouds helped lower temperatures below dangerous level in the San Joaquin Valley on June 28, but high temperatures across the Kern County Deserts were 1-3 Degrees warmer than the previous day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 104 and 109 degrees on June 27.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure anchored from the Four Corners Region north through the Plains into the Southern Canadian provinces, expanded east into the Lower Mississippi Valley on June 14th. Meanwhile, a weak surface trough over portions of East Texas and North Louisiana slowly drifted south during the day, but enhanced compressional warming and moisture pooling over these areas. This contributed in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid and upper 90s, with the oppressively high humidity resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees.

A multi-day excessive heat event occurred across much of the mid-Atlantic near the end of June 2021. High temperatures in the mid to locally upper 90s combined with dew points in the upper 60s to near 70 caused heat index values to reach 105 to 110 over much of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105F on both June 29 and 30.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A historic heat wave affected the Pacific Northwest during this interval.  It was caused by a strong upper level ridge that created dry and stable conditions over the area with strong subsidence.  Many daily, monthly, and all-time high temperature records were set over southwest and south central Oregon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Toketee Falls was the only station from this zone that reported observations. On 06/26/21, the low temperature was 58 degrees and the high temperature was 91 degrees. On 06/27/21, the low temperature was 72 degrees and the high temperature was 103 degrees. On 06/28/21, the low temperature was 62 degrees and the high temperature was 108 degrees. On 06/29/21, the low temperature was 59 degrees and the high temperature was 99 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A historic heat wave affected the Pacific Northwest during this interval.  It was caused by a strong upper level ridge that created dry and stable conditions over the area with strong subsidence.  Many daily, monthly, and all-time high temperature records were set over southwest and south central Oregon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On 06/26/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 51 to 56 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 80 to 91 degrees. On 06/27/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 54 to 62 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 86 to 99 degrees. On 06/28/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 56 to 70 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 88 to 101 degrees. On 06/29/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 56 to 60 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 85 to 99 degrees.

An upper-level ridge centered over the western United States led to excessive heat across the High Deserts and the lower deserts of Southern California from June 1 to June 5. Hot temperatures and very dry conditions primed the region for enhanced fire weather; a wildfire was reported in Riverside County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous heat-related 911 calls were reported across San Diego County from June 2 through June 4. Several were reported due to walking/hiking in the desert. All cases had experienced mild heat-related symptoms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level ridge centered over the western United States led to excessive heat across the High Deserts and the lower deserts of Southern California from June 1 to June 5. Hot temperatures and very dry conditions primed the region for enhanced fire weather; a wildfire was reported in Riverside County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive heat was reported across the Apple and Lucerne Valleys. The heat peaked on Wednesday, June 2, with a high temperature of 104 degrees reported in Apple Valley and a temperature of 97 degrees reported in Hesperia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level ridge centered over the western United States led to excessive heat across the High Deserts and the lower deserts of Southern California from June 1 to June 5. Hot temperatures and very dry conditions primed the region for enhanced fire weather; a wildfire was reported in Riverside County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive heat occurred across the Coachella Valley through this event. The high temperature peaked in Palm Springs on Friday, June 4 when temperatures reached 109 degrees. Thermal and Indio reported their peak temperatures on June 5, with highs of 108 and 107, respectively. Indio also reported an overnight low temperature of 84 degrees on June 5. The Excessive Heat Warning expired on the evening of June 4, so the hottest day of the event for some locations occurred after the expiration.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level ridge centered over the western United States led to excessive heat across the High Deserts and the lower deserts of Southern California from June 1 to June 5. Hot temperatures and very dry conditions primed the region for enhanced fire weather; a wildfire was reported in Riverside County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive heat occurred across the San Diego County Deserts through this evening. Ocotillo Wells reported the highest temperature of the event at 111 degrees on June 5. The heat peaked in Borrego Springs on June 4, when temperatures reached 108 degrees. The Excessive Heat Warning was allowed to expire on the evening of June 4, so the peak heat that occurred on June 5 was not covered by the heat warning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lifting warm front across the region brought a hot and humid air mass into the region, leading to maximum heat indices reaching 95 to 98 degrees across some valley locations of eastern New York.||An approaching cold front from the west led to numerous showers and thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening hours. Some of these storms became severe with several reports of downed trees and power lines. A couple trees fell onto homes with another falling onto a camper trailer. No injuries were reported. A funnel cloud was spotted by an observer in Warren County looking northward toward Lake George. A lightning strike hit a structure near Galway, causing a fire. Sporadic power outages occurred as a result of these storms with more than 1,000 National Grid customers without power in Washington County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: On 06/26/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 55 to 58 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 96 to 100 degrees. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid airmass developed over eastern New York on the 27th and persisted through the 30th. Meanwhile, a weak surface trough over portions of East Texas and North Louisiana slowly drifted south during the day, but enhanced compressional warming and moisture pooling over these areas. This contributed in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid and upper 90s, with the oppressively high humidity resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure originating from the Desert Southwest built westward into California resulting in very hot daytime temperatures across the region and warm overnight low temperatures, particularly in the thermal belts. High to very high heat risk impacted the region with a four day heatwave. Several daily high temperature records were either tied or broken on the 18th. During the event, cooling centers were made available to the public across interior Northern California. A list of the cooling centers available are as follows: five cooling centers in Sacramento County, one in Butte County, seven in Calaveras County, one in Placer County, two in San Joaquin County, two in Tuolumne County, two in Yolo County, and Solano County had two libraries available for cooling.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Motherlode region saw high temperatures reach in excess of 100 degrees with warm overnight lows.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure centered over the Pacific Northwest brought record high temperatures over the weekend. The heatwave was widespread across the Northwestern United Sates. The Northern Sacramento Valley saw high temperatures reach in excess of 110 degrees over the weekend. Well above normal temperatures in the central and northern Sacramento Valley brought very high heat risk to the area. Several daily high temperature records were broken in the Northern Sacramento Valley on the Saturday the 26th. During the event, two cooling centers were made available to the public in Shasta County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On June 26th, Redding and Red Bluff broke daily high temperature records of 114 and 115 degrees respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure situated over the Desert Southwest led to excessive heat conditions across the Phoenix area as temperatures climbed near 110 degrees. In Phoenix on the 12th, the afternoon high temperature fell one degree short of tying the daily record of 110 degrees. According to local media reports, a couple from Rhode Island started hiking around noon on the 12th at Brown's Ranch Trailhead in Scottsdale. After splitting up during the hike, the wife never returned to their meeting location. Local authorities responded and discovered that the wife had succumbed to the heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A couple from Rhode Island started hiking around noon on the 12th at Brown's Ranch Trailhead in Scottsdale. After splitting up during the hike, the wife never returned to their meeting location. Local authorities from various agencies responded to search for the missing woman. Shortly after 2100MST, local authorities found the missing woman who had succumbed to the heat.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A high pressure heat dome over the region led to stretch of extreme heat, shattering records from June 26 through June 29. All time max temperatures were broken by 8 to 10 degrees. Widespread fatalities occurred due to the heat (123 in total), as many were without air-conditioning, as well as an increase in the number of drownings. Widespread closures and postponements of businesses and events also occurred. Multnomah County had the largest number of fatalities in the state with 73 deaths directly related to the heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were two consecutive days with maximum temperatures greater than 100 degrees. The hottest day was June 27 where temperatures in the area peaked around 112 degrees. Record breaking temperatures up to 111 degrees F in Eugene, OR. There were one heat related deaths reported.

CZ_NAME: MOUNTAINS SOUTHWESTERN SHASTA COUNTY TO WESTERN COLUSA COUNTY
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure ridging brought the first major heat event of the year to Northern California. Widespread moderate to high heat risk impacted the region Memorial Day weekend and into the first few days of June. Some Valley locations reached over 100 degrees for the first time this year. Temperatures generally reached upwards of 20 to 25 degrees above climatology. Several new daily high temperature records and one record monthly high temperature record were set in the area at the peak of the heatwave on the last day of May. There were three cooling centers open in Sacramento County, one in Yolo County, one in Butte County and one in San Joaquin County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At the peak of the heat wave on the 31st, The western foothills of the Sacramento Valley saw high temperatures reach 102 to 103 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge anchored over West Texas into Western Oklahoma and Western Kansas expanded farther east into the Central and Southern Plains on September 1st and 2nd, resulting in a return of very hot temperatures as readings rose back into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees across portions of North Louisiana. A southerly low level flow maintained the very humid conditions in place, with little mixing of dewpoints observed, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees on the 1st, and 105-108 degrees on the 2nd. A weak backdoor surface trough drifted southwest into North Louisiana on the 2nd, which focused isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms near the boundary during the afternoon. This boundary allowed for drier air to spill southwest into the area by the 3rd, resulting in slightly lower heat indices closer to 100 degrees.

An upper level ridge of high pressure anchored from the Four Corners Region north through the Plains into the Southern Canadian provinces, expanded east into the Lower Mississippi Valley on June 14th. Meanwhile, a weak surface trough over portions of East Texas and North Louisiana slowly drifted south during the day, but enhanced compressional warming and moisture pooling over these areas. This contributed in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid and upper 90s, with the oppressively high humidity resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees.

An upper level ridge anchored over West Texas into Western Oklahoma and Western Kansas expanded farther east into the Central and Southern Plains on September 1st, resulting in a return of very hot temperatures as readings rose back into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees across all of the Four State Region. A southerly low level flow maintained the very humid conditions in place, with little mixing of dewpoints observed, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees across Bowie and Cass Counties in Northeast Texas. Slightly cooler temperatures were observed on the 2nd as a weak surface trough drifted southwest into the area from Southwest Arkansas, which resulted in scattered showers and thunderstorms during the early morning hours over portions of Southwest Arkansas and extreme Northeast Texas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A high pressure heat dome over the region led to stretch of extreme heat, shattering records from June 26 through June 29. All time max temperatures were broken by 8 to 10 degrees. Widespread fatalities occurred due to the heat (123 in total), as many were without air-conditioning, as well as an increase in the number of drownings. Widespread closures and postponements of businesses and events also occurred. Multnomah County had the largest number of fatalities in the state with 73 deaths directly related to the heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures across the area reached into the 100s and lower 110s over a three day period. This lead to many people seeking locations to cool off. A young girl drowned in the Hood River on Wednesday, June 30.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot weather began to develop August 9, peaking August 11-12, but temperatures continued above normal into the weekend. Peak afternoon temperatures of 100 to 105 degrees drove people to seek relief in or near bodies of water. Heat caused slowdowns on the MAX light rail (Portland metro area) systems, and some businesses did close due to the heat. Cooling shelters were opened in several counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The high temperature at Hillsboro (KHIO) was 103 degrees on the 11th and 12th, while it was 102 degrees on the 11th and 103 degrees on the 12th at Portland International Airport (KPDX).

Some Valley locations reached over 100 degrees for the first time this year. Several new record daily high temperatures and one record monthly high temperature record were set in the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High pressure ridging brought a heat wave to Northern California over the Memorial Day weekend holiday. Temperatures reached upwards of 20 to 25 degrees above climatology. Several new record daily high temperatures and one record monthly high temperature record were set in the area. At the peak of the heat wave on the 31st, Redding reached 109 breaking both the daily and monthly high temperature records. Red Bluff reached 108, setting a new daily high temperature record. Downtown Sacramento hit 106 tying the daily high temperature record. Sacramento Executive Airport reached 105 setting a new daily high temperature record. There were three cooling centers open in Sacramento County, one in Yolo County, one in Butte County and one in San Joaquin County.

Widespread fatalities occurred due to the heat (123 in total), as many were without air-conditioning, as well as an increase in the number of drownings. Widespread closures and postponements of businesses and events also occurred. Multnomah County had the largest number of fatalities in the state with 73 deaths directly related to the heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures across the area reached into the 90s. This led to many people seeking locations to cool off. A middle-aged woman drowned on Monday, June 28.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure ridging brought the first major heat event of the year to Northern California. Widespread moderate to high heat risk impacted the region Memorial Day weekend and into the first few days of June. Some Valley locations reached over 100 degrees for the first time this year. Temperatures generally reached upwards of 20 to 25 degrees above climatology. Several new daily high temperature records and one record monthly high temperature record were set in the area at the peak of the heatwave on the last day of May. There were three cooling centers open in Sacramento County, one in Yolo County, one in Butte County and one in San Joaquin County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At the peak of the heat wave on the 31st, the Northern San Joaquin Valley saw high temperatures reach just over 100 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure originating from the Desert Southwest built westward into California resulting in very hot daytime temperatures across the region and warm overnight low temperatures, particularly in the thermal belts. High to very high heat risk impacted the region with a four day heatwave. Several daily high temperature records were either tied or broken on the 18th. During the event, cooling centers were made available to the public across interior Northern California. A list of the cooling centers available are as follows: five cooling centers in Sacramento County, one in Butte County, seven in Calaveras County, one in Placer County, two in San Joaquin County, two in Tuolumne County, two in Yolo County, and Solano County had two libraries available for cooling.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Northern San Joaquin Valley saw high temperatures reach over 105 degrees during the event. On June 18th, Stockton tied the daily high temperature record of 108 and Modesto recorded a record daily high temperature of 107 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first major heat event of the year brought widespread moderate to high heat risk Memorial Day weekend to Northern California. Some Valley locations reached over 100 degrees for the first time this year. Several new record daily high temperatures and one record monthly high temperature record were set in the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High pressure ridging brought a heat wave to Northern California over the Memorial Day weekend holiday. Temperatures reached upwards of 20 to 25 degrees above climatology. Several new record daily high temperatures and one record monthly high temperature record were set in the area. At the peak of the heat wave on the 31st, Redding reached 109 breaking both the daily and monthly high temperature records. Red Bluff reached 108, setting a new daily high temperature record. Downtown Sacramento hit 106 tying the daily high temperature record. Sacramento Executive Airport reached 105 setting a new daily high temperature record. There were three cooling centers open in Sacramento County, one in Yolo County, one in Butte County and one in San Joaquin County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first major heat event of the year brought widespread moderate to high heat risk Memorial Day weekend to Northern California. EVENT_NARRATIVE: High pressure ridging brought a heat wave to Northern California over the Memorial Day weekend holiday. Temperatures reached upwards of 20 to 25 degrees above climatology. Several new record daily high temperatures and one record monthly high temperature record were set in the area. Downtown Sacramento hit 106 tying the daily high temperature record. Sacramento Executive Airport reached 105 setting a new daily high temperature record. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge anchored over West Texas into Western Oklahoma and Western Kansas expanded farther east into the Central and Southern Plains on September 1st and 2nd, resulting in a return of very hot temperatures as readings rose back into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees across much of East Texas. A southerly low level flow maintained the very humid conditions in place, with little mixing of dewpoints observed, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees across East Texas. A weak backdoor surface trough drifted southwest into East Texas on the 2nd, which focused isolated to widely scattered showers and thunderstorms near the boundary during the afternoon. This boundary allowed for drier air to spill southwest into the area by the 3rd, resulting in slightly lower heat indices closer to 100 degrees.

A very strong upper ridge built inland into California during the Memorial Day holiday weekend resulting in temperatures rising to near record levels across the San Joaquin Valley and the West Side Hills by Memorial Day (May 31). Several stations across these areas had maximum temperatures exceed the century mark on May 31 prompting the issuance of Excessive Heat Warnings and the opening of cooling centers due to this event taking place early in the season.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 101 and 105 degrees on May 31.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A high pressure heat dome over the region led to stretch of extreme heat, shattering records from June 26 through June 29. All time max temperatures were broken by 8 to 10 degrees. Widespread fatalities occurred due to the heat (123 in total), as many were without air-conditioning, as well as an increase in the number of drownings. Widespread closures and postponements of businesses and events also occurred. Multnomah County had the largest number of fatalities in the state with 73 deaths directly related to the heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Record breaking temperatures for 3 days in a row. Portland International recorded high temperatures of 108, 112, and 116 F (breaking its previous all time record of 107), and low temperatures of 70, 73, and 75 F. The Oregon State Police and Oregon Medical Examiner reported 67 deaths in Multnomah County from the heat, but it is suspected this fatality count is closer to 71. There were also reports of roads buckling due to heat. Cooling shelters were opened and many businesses closed and events postponed.

The combination of high temperatures in the mid 90's and high humidity resulted in hazardous heat indices in the 105 to 110 degree range across parts of southeast Missouri. These high readings were confined to areas along and southwest of a line from New Madrid to Dexter to Greenville. Locally even higher heat indices from 110 to 113 were observed over the Ozark foothills counties of Carter and Ripley. A weak cold front made its way southward across southeast Missouri, but not fast enough to prevent another afternoon of hazardous heat indices.

Locally even higher heat indices from 110 to 113 were observed over the Ozark foothills counties of Carter and Ripley. A weak cold front made its way southward across southeast Missouri, but not fast enough to prevent another afternoon of hazardous heat indices.

An upper level ridge anchored over West Texas into Western Oklahoma and Western Kansas expanded farther east into the Central and Southern Plains on September 1st and 2nd, resulting in a return of very hot temperatures as readings rose back into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees across much of East Texas. A southerly low level flow maintained the very humid conditions in place, with little mixing of dewpoints observed, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees across East Texas. A weak backdoor surface trough drifted southwest into East Texas on the 2nd, which focused isolated to widely scattered showers and thunderstorms near the boundary during the afternoon. This boundary allowed for drier air to spill southwest into the area by the 3rd, resulting in slightly lower heat indices closer to 100 degrees.

High pressure ridging brought the first major heat event of the year to Northern California. Widespread moderate to high heat risk impacted the region Memorial Day weekend and into the first few days of June. Some Valley locations reached over 100 degrees for the first time this year. Temperatures generally reached upwards of 20 to 25 degrees above climatology. Several new daily high temperature records and one record monthly high temperature record were set in the area at the peak of the heatwave on the last day of May. There were three cooling centers open in Sacramento County, one in Yolo County, one in Butte County and one in San Joaquin County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At the peak of the heat wave on the 31st, the Motherlode region saw high temperatures reach in mid 90s to around 100 degrees.

An upper level ridge anchored over West Texas into Western Oklahoma and Western Kansas expanded farther east into the Central and Southern Plains on September 1st, resulting in a return of very hot temperatures as readings rose back into the mid and upper 90s across North Central Louisiana. A southerly low level flow maintained the very humid conditions in place, with little mixing of dewpoints observed, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees across North Central Louisiana. A weak backdoor surface trough drifted southwest into North Louisiana from Southwest Arkansas throughout the day on the 2nd, which focused isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms near the boundary from the early morning through the afternoon. This boundary allowed for drier air to spill southwest into the area, resulting in slightly lower heat indices closer to 100 degrees.

A southerly low level flow maintained the very humid conditions in place, with little mixing of dewpoints observed, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees on the 1st, and 105-108 degrees on the 2nd. Under the influence of a strong ridge aloft, hot temperatures combined with high humidity levels to produce dangerous heat indices across southeast South Carolina. Numerous observation sites reported heat index values in excess of 115 degrees for several hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several observations sites around Berkeley County reported heat index values of 115 degrees or greater for several hours in the afternoon. This includes the Witherbee Remote Automatic Weather Station (RAWS) site located near Huger.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad upper level ridge over the Desert Southwest led to excessive heat conditions across portions of southeast California.

High pressure over California resulted in very hot daytime temperatures and warm overnight low temperatures across interior Northern California. High to very high heat risk impacted the region. One daily high temperature record was broken. During the event, cooling centers were made available to the public across interior Northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Burney Basin region saw high temperatures reach over 100 degrees during the event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: It was the hottest June ever recorded at Challis with an average monthly temperature of 70.1 degrees which was 9.2 degrees above the monthly normal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: It was the hottest June ever recorded at Challis with an average monthly temperature of 70.1 degrees which was 9.2 degrees above the monthly normal.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: It was the hottest June ever recorded at Stanley with an average monthly temperature of 58.3 degrees which was 6.7 degrees above the monthly normal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: It was the hottest June ever recorded at Stanley with an average monthly temperature of 58.3 degrees which was 6.7 degrees above the monthly normal.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure brought another long-lived heat wave to northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reported observations from this zone were sparse.  Fort Jones reported a high of 104 degrees on 07/12 and a low of 54 degrees on 7/13.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure brought another heat wave to southern Oregon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On 07/29/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 53 to 66 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 90 to 103 degrees. On 07/30/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 58 to 71 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 90 to 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure brought another heat wave to southern Oregon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On 07/29/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 56 to 68 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 96 to 104 degrees. On 07/30/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 55 to 70 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 93 to 99 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure brought another heat wave to northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On 07/29/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 61 to 63 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 100 to 102 degrees. On 07/30/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 65 to 69 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 98 to 102 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge anchored over West Texas into Western Oklahoma and Western Kansas expanded farther east into the Central and Southern Plains on September 1st, resulting in a return of very hot temperatures as readings rose back into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees across all of the Four State Region. A southerly low level flow maintained the very humid conditions in place, with little mixing of dewpoints observed, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees across Bowie and Cass Counties in Northeast Texas. Slightly cooler temperatures were observed on the 2nd as a weak surface trough drifted southwest into the area from Southwest Arkansas, which resulted in scattered showers and thunderstorms during the early morning hours over portions of Southwest Arkansas and extreme Northeast Texas.

One daily high temperature record was broken. During the event, cooling centers were made available to the public across interior Northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake Shasta Dam saw high temperatures reach 104 degrees during the event.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Northern Sacramento Valley saw high temperatures reach in excess of 105 degrees, with Redding airport reaching 108 degrees during the event.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At the peak of the heatwave on the 31st, Downtown Sacramento hit 106 tying the daily high temperature record and Sacramento Executive Airport reached 105 setting a new daily high temperature record.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure ridging brought the first major heat event of the year to Northern California. Widespread moderate to high heat risk impacted the region Memorial Day weekend and into the first few days of June. Some Valley locations reached over 100 degrees for the first time this year. Temperatures generally reached upwards of 20 to 25 degrees above climatology. Several new daily high temperature records and one record monthly high temperature record were set in the area at the peak of the heatwave on the last day of May. There were three cooling centers open in Sacramento County, one in Yolo County, one in Butte County and one in San Joaquin County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At the peak of the heatwave on the 31st, Redding reached 109 breaking both the daily and monthly high temperature records. Red Bluff reached 108, setting a new daily high temperature record.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure centered over the Pacific Northwest brought record high temperatures over the weekend. The heatwave was widespread across the Northwestern United Sates. The Northern Sacramento Valley saw high temperatures reach in excess of 110 degrees over the weekend. Well above normal temperatures in the central and northern Sacramento Valley brought very high heat risk to the area. Several daily high temperature records were broken in the Northern Sacramento Valley on the Saturday the 26th. During the event, two cooling centers were made available to the public in Shasta County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake Shasta Dam saw high temperatures reach 108 to 109 degrees over the weekend.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure anchored from the Four Corners Region north through the Plains into the Southern Canadian provinces, expanded east into the Lower Mississippi Valley on June 14th. Meanwhile, a weak surface trough over portions of East Texas and North Louisiana slowly drifted south during the day, but enhanced compressional warming and moisture pooling over these areas. This contributed in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid and upper 90s, with the oppressively high humidity resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees.

A strong dome of hot high pressure over the Inland Northwest pushed afternoon high temperatures into record territory. In late June 2021, a long-lived heatwave broke many daily, monthly, and all time maximum high and low temperature records at several stations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperature observations taken in Wallace and St. Maries, Idaho were unseasonably warm from June 28th through June 30th. The high temperatures were at, or above, 100 degrees all three days. St. Maries set a new maximum June temperature when reaching 108 degrees on the 30th. There are no known heat-related deaths.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong dome of hot high pressure over the Inland Northwest pushed afternoon high temperatures into record territory. In late June 2021, a long-lived heatwave broke many daily, monthly, and all time maximum high and low temperature records at several stations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three locations reached an all time record high temperature on the afternoon of June 28th: Priest River at 108 degrees, Sandpoint at 106 degrees, and Bonners Ferry at 108 degrees. Priest River and Blanchard set up cooling centers to help those without air conditioning. There are no known heat related deaths.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong dome of hot high pressure over the Inland Northwest pushed afternoon high temperatures into record territory. In late June 2021, a long-lived heatwave broke many daily, monthly, and all time maximum high and low temperature records at several stations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Republic reached an all time record high temperature of 109 degrees on the afternoon of June 28th. On June 30th, there was a report, from the Washington State Department of Transportation, that there was damage to road surfaces at Sherman Pass due to the heat. Local libraries were arranged to act as cooling centers across the area. There are no known heat related deaths.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong dome of hot high pressure over the Inland Northwest pushed afternoon high temperatures into record territory. In late June 2021, a long-lived heatwave broke many daily, monthly, and all time maximum high and low temperature records at several stations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two locations reached an all time record high temperature on the afternoon of June 28th: Plain at 109 degrees and Mazama at 112 degrees. Local broadcast news reported that, near Inspiration Lake, a hiker was rescued after suffering from heat exposure. Local libraries were arranged to act as cooling centers across the area. There are no known heat related deaths.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong dome of hot high pressure over the Inland Northwest pushed afternoon high temperatures into record territory. In late June 2021, a long-lived heatwave broke many daily, monthly, and all time maximum high and low temperature records at several stations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: From June 26th through 30th, peak temperatures across the Okanogan Valley reached 100 to 117 degrees. Overnight low temperatures cooled to a warm 67 to 73 degrees. Omak reached an all time record high temperature of 117 degrees on the afternoon of June 29th. Local libraries were arranged to act as cooling centers for those with out air conditioning across the area. A report from the Washington Department of Health stated that there were four heat-related deaths in Okanogan County. Further specifics were statewide and not given by counties.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong dome of hot high pressure over the Inland Northwest pushed afternoon high temperatures into record territory. In late June 2021, a long-lived heatwave broke many daily, monthly, and all time maximum high and low temperature records at several stations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: From June 26th through July 2nd, the town of Mansfield recorded six consecutive days with a high temperature at 100 degrees or above. Local cooling centers were set up by emergency management for those without air conditioning across the area. A report from the Washington Department of Health stated that there were two heat-related deaths in Douglas County. Further specifics were statewide and not given by counties.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong dome of hot high pressure over the Inland Northwest pushed afternoon high temperatures into record territory. In late June 2021, a long-lived heatwave broke many daily, monthly, and all time maximum high and low temperature records at several stations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The town of Northport set a new all-time maximum temperature of 113 degrees on June 28th. Over a five day range, Deer Park Airport afternoon highs reached 100 to 111 degrees and one overnight low only cooled to 74 degrees. There was a report, from the Washington State Department of Transportation, that there was roadway peeling on State Route 20, west of Tiger. There are no known heat related deaths.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong dome of hot high pressure over the Inland Northwest pushed afternoon high temperatures into record territory. In late June 2021, a long-lived heatwave broke many daily, monthly, and all time maximum high and low temperature records at several stations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two new all time record high maximum temperatures were set across the upper Columbia Basin on June 28th: Wilbur reached 110 degrees and Odessa 115 degrees. Due to the extreme high temperatures, local libraries for those without air conditioning across the area. There are no known heat related deaths.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong dome of hot high pressure over the Inland Northwest pushed afternoon high temperatures into record territory. In late June 2021, a long-lived heatwave broke many daily, monthly, and all time maximum high and low temperature records at several stations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A period of excessive heat left numerous heat-related impacts and new all time record high maximum temperatures in the Spokane Metropolitan area. Spokane International Airport broke their record when they observed an afternoon high of 109 degrees on June 28th. The record warmest low temperature followed on June 30th when only cooling to 78 degrees. Avista Utilities performed two blackouts due to the heat which impacted approximately 8300 customers. There are eight known heat-related deaths in Spokane County. There are no other known specifics about the fatalities.

This contributed in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid and upper 90s, with the oppressively high humidity resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees.

An upper level ridge of high pressure anchored from the Four Corners Region north through the Plains into the Southern Canadian provinces, expanded east into the Lower Mississippi Valley on June 14th. Meanwhile, a weak surface trough over portions of East Texas and North Louisiana slowly drifted south during the day, but enhanced compressional warming and moisture pooling over these areas. This contributed in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid and upper 90s, with the oppressively high humidity resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees.

Very warm temperatures occurred inland on September 20-22, with highs reaching 95 to 105 degrees. Weak Santa Ana winds brought breezy conditions to the mountains and Inland Empire. Multiple wildfire starts in the Inland Empire, with fires exacerbated by hot conditions and dry vegetation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Anaheim broke the daily record for maximum high temperature on September 21. Anaheim recorded a high of 104 degrees, breaking the record of 102 set in 2015.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very warm temperatures occurred inland on September 20-22, with highs reaching 95 to 105 degrees. Weak Santa Ana winds brought breezy conditions to the mountains and Inland Empire. Multiple wildfire starts in the Inland Empire, with fires exacerbated by hot conditions and dry vegetation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Alpine broke the highest maximum temperature record for September 21 with an observed high of 98 degrees, breaking the record of 97 degrees set in 2009. Ramona tied their high temperature record with a high of 101 degrees, which tied for the same date in 1975.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Vista tied the maximum high temperature record for September 21 reaching a high of 95 degrees, tying for the same date set in 1992.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Campo tied for the highest maximum temperature for September 22, reaching a high of 101 degrees, tying for this same date in 1982.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper high pressure center strengthened over the Great Basin during the Labor Day weekend (September 4 to September 6) resulting in temperatures rising to much above normal levels over the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and Kern County Deserts on September 6.  The dangerous heat remained prevalent over the area through September 9 prompting the issuance of heat highlights as the large upper high prodcued a pronounced southeast flow over the area.  A trough moved into northern California during the morning of September 10 bringing an end to the dangerous heat as afternoon highs remained below the century mark at most stations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 102 and 107 degrees on September 6, 7 and 8.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level ridge of high pressure and a surface thermal trough brought several days of record high temperatures across the PacNW, with many locations in the lower and higher elevations experiencing extreme heat risk during this event. The multiple days of extreme heat risk has been attributed to several fatalities across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The GHCN station for Kennewick, WA recorded consecutive days between June 27th through July 1st of temperatures that met or exceeded excessive heat warning criteria. Several fatalities across Benton and Franklin counties were attributed to the heat wave during this period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level ridge of high pressure and a surface thermal trough brought several days of record high temperatures across the PacNW, with many locations in the lower and higher elevations experiencing extreme heat risk during this event. The multiple days of extreme heat risk has been attributed to several fatalities across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Calculated heat risk values at the KYKM ASOS recorded consecutive days between June 26th through July 1st of temperatures that met or exceeded excessive heat warning criteria. The Yakima county Coroner' Office reported 4 fatalities that heat was a contributing factor to during the heat wave, however, no additional details were provided regarding age, sex, actual date, or location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure brought another long-lived heat wave to northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On 07/09/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 56 to 58 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 105 to 108 degrees. On 07/10/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 60 to 66 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 105 to 108 degrees. On 07/11/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 60 to 65 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 105 to 106 degrees. On 07/12/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 62 to 66 degrees and the reported high temperatures were all 101 degrees. On 07/13/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 59 to 63 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 100 to 101 degrees. Siskiyou/Montague airport (KSIY) reported a record high for 7/09 with 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure building over the region in early to mid July brought warm to hot temperatures across the interior. Daytime highs rose into the 100s with locations across the East Bay up to 110 degrees between July 9th and 11th. Overnight lows remained warm, particularly across higher elevations where temperatures were still in the 70s and 80s in the early mornings. Additionally, prolonged dry conditions resulted in near record dry fuels for July. This along with breezy afternoon winds prompted the Diablo Fire in Contra Costa County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet (PG&E) station at Ida Clayton Road reported overnight minimum temperature of 87 degrees F.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures were experienced on May 6 with high temperatures in the lower to middle 90s in southern Cochise County. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one female found north of the International Border west of Douglas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures around 10 degrees above normal, near 95, occurred in southern Cochise County causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached on May 6. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one female found a few days later near the International Border west of Douglas, but the exact date of the fatality was undetermined.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures were experienced on May 13 with high temperatures in the upper 90s on the Tohono O'odham Nation. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one male found in the desert west of Sells.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures around 10 degrees above normal, 95 to 100, occurred on the Tohono O'odham Nation causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached on May 13. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one male near west of Sells.
