EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of high temperatures in the lower 90's and high humidity resulted in potentially hazardous heat indices. The peak heat index ranged from 106 to 110 degrees across most of southern Illinois, except locally 115 degrees around Mount Vernon. A strong 500 mb high over the Plains states moved far enough east to bring oppressive heat to the region. At the surface, a hot westerly wind flow occurred ahead of a weak cold front.

The peak heat index ranged from 106 to 110 degrees across most of southern Illinois, except locally 115 degrees around Mount Vernon. A strong upper level ridge of high pressure and a surface thermal trough brought several days of record high temperatures across the PacNW, with many locations in the lower and higher elevations experiencing extreme heat risk during this event. The multiple days of extreme heat risk has been attributed to several fatalities across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Calculated heat risk values at the KDLS ASOS recorded consecutive days between June 25th through June 29th  of temperatures that met or exceeded excessive heat warning criteria. Several locations including the KDLS ASOS recorded consecutive days over 110 degrees through the period, with KDLS recording 118 degrees on June 28th.

A high pressure heat dome over the region led to stretch of extreme heat, shattering records from June 26 through June 29. All time max temperatures were broken by 8 to 10 degrees. Widespread fatalities occurred due to the heat (123 in total), as many were without air-conditioning, as well as an increase in the number of drownings. Widespread closures and postponements of businesses and events also occurred. Multnomah County had the largest number of fatalities in the state with 73 deaths directly related to the heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures across the area warmed into the 100s to mid 110s over a three day period. Record breaking temperatures up to 117 degrees were recorded in Salem, OR. A total of 18 heat related deaths were reported, including two middle aged men who drowned in the Willamette River on Saturday, June 26.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper high pressure center strengthened over the Great Basin during the Labor Day weekend (September 4 to September 6) resulting in temperatures rising to much above normal levels over the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and Kern County Deserts on September 6.  The dangerous heat remained prevalent over the area through September 9 prompting the issuance of heat highlights as the large upper high prodcued a pronounced southeast flow over the area.  A trough moved into northern California during the morning of September 10 bringing an end to the dangerous heat as afternoon highs remained below the century mark at most stations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 102 and 107 degrees on September 6, 7 and 8.

Scattered strong to severe thunderstorms developed across western Connecticut during the afternoon hours of Wednesday, July 7th, 2021. These storms resulted in a report of a downed tree in Litchfield county.||Additionally, heat indices across southern Litchfield county exceeded 95 degrees during the afternoon hours.

Upper-level high pressure parked over the region resulting in a period of unseasonably hot weather across the Mid-South during the end of July.  High temperatures combined with high humidity to produce afternoon heat index values of 105 degrees or higher.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105 to 110 degrees in the afternoon and early evening.

A large upper high pressure ridge built into central California between July 7 and July 9 and remained over the region through July 13 before shifting east and allowing for moderating temperatures across the area by July 14. This ridge was responsible for several days of near record heat across the area and resulted in the most significant hot spell across the area since the heat wave of July 16-27, 2006. The main saving grace; however, was that humidity was not as high as it was during the 2006 heat wave which lessened it's destructive impact.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 108 and 115 degrees on July 7-9 and between 112 and 120 degrees on July 10-13.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours of Tuesday, July 6th, 2021, as an upper level disturbance tracked through the region. Several downed trees and wires resulted from the strongest storms. More than 35,000 customers lost power.||Additionally, heat indices across the Mid-Hudson valley and southern Taconics exceeded 95 degrees during the afternoon hours.

A strong upper level ridge of high pressure and a surface thermal trough brought several days of record high temperatures across the PacNW, with many locations in the lower and higher elevations experiencing extreme heat risk during this event. The multiple days of extreme heat risk has been attributed to several fatalities across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearly all RAWS stations across the zone recorded consecutive daily high temperatures over 100 degrees through the period, while the Goldendale East RAWS site recorded a high temperature of 110 degrees on June 29th.

CZ_NAME: EAST SLOPES OF THE WASHINGTON CASCADES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level ridge of high pressure and a surface thermal trough brought several days of record high temperatures across the PacNW, with many locations in the lower and higher elevations experiencing extreme heat risk during this event. The multiple days of extreme heat risk has been attributed to several fatalities across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several RAWS stations across the zone recorded consecutive daily high temperatures over 95 degrees through the period, with the Sawmill Flats, Swauk, and Buck Creek RAWS sites having recorded consecutive daily high temperatures over 100 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level ridge of high pressure and a surface thermal trough brought several days of record high temperatures across the PacNW, with many locations in the lower and higher elevations experiencing extreme heat risk during this event. The multiple days of extreme heat risk has been attributed to several fatalities across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Calculated heat risk values at the KDLS ASOS recorded consecutive days between June 25th through June 29th  of temperatures that met or exceeded excessive heat warning criteria. Several locations including the KDLS ASOS recorded consecutive days over 110 degrees through the period, with KDLS recording 118 degrees on June 28th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level ridge of high pressure and a surface thermal trough brought several days of record high temperatures across the PacNW, with many locations in the lower and higher elevations experiencing extreme heat risk during this event. The multiple days of extreme heat risk has been attributed to several fatalities across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Calculated heat risk values at the KYKM ASOS recorded consecutive days between June 26th through July 1st of temperatures that met or exceeded excessive heat warning criteria. Calculated heat risk values at the GHCN station at Selah 2 NE recorded consecutive days between June 26th through June 30th of temperatures that met or exceeded excessive heat warning criteria. The Yakima county Coroner' Office reported 4 fatalities that heat was a contributing factor to during the heat wave, however, no additional details were provided regarding age, sex, actual date, or location.

The combination of high temperatures in the lower to mid 90's and high humidity resulted in potentially hazardous heat indices. The peak heat index ranged from 106 to 111 degrees across western Kentucky. A strong 500 mb high over the Plains states moved far enough east to bring oppressive heat to the region. At the surface, a hot westerly wind flow occurred ahead of a weak cold front.

A large upper high pressure ridge built into central California between July 7 and July 9 and remained over the region through July 13 before shifting east and allowing for moderating temperatures across the area by July 14. This ridge was responsible for several days of near record heat across the area and resulted in the most significant hot spell across the area since the heat wave of July 16-27, 2006. The main saving grace; however, was that humidity was not as high as it was during the 2006 heat wave which lessened it's destructive impact.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 107 and 113 degrees on July 9-11 and between 105 and 111 degrees on July 12-13.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level ridge of high pressure and a surface thermal trough brought several days of record high temperatures across the PacNW, with many locations in the lower and higher elevations experiencing extreme heat risk during this event. The multiple days of extreme heat risk has been attributed to several fatalities across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Calculated heat risk at the KRLD AWOS recorded consecutive days between June 26th through June 30th of temperatures that met or exceeded excessive heat warning criteria. The GHCN station for Kennewick, WA recorded consecutive days between June 27th through July 1st of temperatures that met or exceeded excessive heat warning criteria. The KRLD AWOS and the KPSC ASOS recorded consecutive daily high temperatures over 110 degrees, with KRLD measuring 118 degrees on June 29th. Several fatalities across Benton and Franklin counties were attributed to the heat wave during this period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Under the influence of a strong ridge aloft, hot temperatures combined with high humidity levels to produce dangerous heat indices across southeast South Carolina. Numerous observation sites reported heat index values in excess of 115 degrees for several hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several sites around Beaufort County observed heat index values of 115 degrees in the afternoon hours. The observation sites include the Beaufort Marine Corps Air Station (KNBC).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Under the influence of a strong ridge aloft, hot temperatures combined with high humidity levels to produce dangerous heat indices across southeast South Carolina. Numerous observation sites reported heat index values in excess of 115 degrees for several hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several observations sites around Charleston County reported heat index values of 115 degrees or greater for several hours in the afternoon. This includes the Wambaw Remote Automatic Weather Station (RAWS) site located near Awendaw. The maximum heat index observed was 118 degrees by a weather station at the Forest Park playground in the West Ashley area, which is operated and maintained by the City of Charleston.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid air mass developed ahead of an approaching cold front across eastern New York on Thursday, August 26, 2021. Heat indices reached 95 to 101 degrees across most areas outside of the higher elevations during the afternoon hours.||The cold front slowly dropped southward during the day on Friday, August 27, 2021, but heat indices still reached 95 to 100 degrees across portions of the mid-Hudson Valley during the afternoon prior to the frontal passage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure building over the region in early to mid July brought warm to hot temperatures across the interior. Daytime highs rose into the 100s with locations across the East Bay up to 110 degrees between July 9th and 11th. Overnight lows remained warm, particularly across higher elevations where temperatures were still in the 70s and 80s in the early mornings. Additionally, prolonged dry conditions resulted in near record dry fuels for July. This along with breezy afternoon winds prompted the Diablo Fire in Contra Costa County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cazadero CWOP station reported high temperature of 109 degrees F.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms developed along a stalled frontal boundary during the afternoon hours of Wednesday, July 7th, 2021. Several reports of downed trees and wires resulted from the severe storms. A microburst was confirmed in Columbia and Greene Counties where an estimated 70 to 90 mph winds caused significant damage in the towns of Coxsackie and Stuyvesant. A state of emergency was declared in the town of Coxsackie as a result of the damage. ||A second round of severe thunderstorms moved into eastern New York during the late evening of the 7th into the early morning of the 8th with a few reports of downed trees.||Additionally, heat indices across the mid-Hudson Valley and southern Taconics exceeded 95 degrees during the afternoon.

A high pressure heat dome over the region led to stretch of extreme heat, shattering records from June 26 through June 29. Hot temperatures resulted in many people seeking locations to cool off in local rivers and beaches, which led to one drowning, as well as multiple people going to local hospitals for treatment of typical heat-related medical symptoms, including one reported death.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures. A Mesonet Weather Station near Underwood observed three consecutive days with temperatures above 105 degrees. This station reported a maximum temperature of 107 on June 26, 113 on June 27, and 115 on June 28. The minimum temperatures were in the lower 70s on June 27 and June 28.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A high pressure heat dome over the region led to stretch of extreme heat, shattering records from June 26 through June 29. Hot temperatures resulted in many people seeking locations to cool off in local rivers and beaches, which led to one drowning, as well as multiple people going to local hospitals for treatment of typical heat-related medical symptoms, including one reported death.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures. There were three consecutive days with maximum temperatures above 100 degrees. Maximum temperatures peaked around 108 degrees on June 27, and 112 degrees on June 28. The minimum temperatures were in the mid 70s on June 27 and June 28.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level ridging strengthened over the Mid-South late in July as dewpoints surged to near 80 degrees across parts of the region. High temperatures combined with the high dewpoints to produce heat index values of 110 degrees or higher.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 110 degrees or higher in the afternoon and early evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level ridging strengthened over the Mid-South late in July as dewpoints surged to near 80 degrees across parts of the region. High temperatures combined with the high dewpoints to produce heat index values of 110 degrees or higher.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 110 degrees or higher in the afternoon and early evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several days of oppressive heat created hazardous conditions. From the 24th to the 29th, heat indices peaked above 100 degrees each afternoon. At the Carbondale airport, the highest heat index of this multi-day period was 109 degrees on the 25th. A very persistent area of high pressure centered over the Appalachian Mountains produced a long duration of hot and humid south winds.

Upper level ridging built back in over the Ark-La-Tex during the second week of August, resulting in a return of afternoon temperatures back into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees across Southwest Arkansas. Southerly winds maintained the very humid conditions in place, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-108 degrees from August 9th-12th. A weak frontal system and associated showers and thunderstorms moved into the region on the 13th, bringing about several days of needed rainfall and cooler temperatures.

Upper level ridging built back in over the Ark-La-Tex during the second week of August, resulting in a return of afternoon temperatures back into the mid and upper 90s across East Texas. Southerly winds maintained the very humid conditions in place, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees across portions of East Texas, mainly counties bordering the Red River, the Louisiana state line, as well as much of Deep East Texas from August 9th-12th. A weak frontal system and associated showers and thunderstorms moved into the region on the 13th, bringing about several days of needed rainfall and cooler temperatures.

An upper level ridge of high pressure was anchored from Nebraska/Kansas southeast into portions of the Lower Mississippi Valley from July 25th through the end of the month, resulting in very hot temperatures across the Ark-La-Tex as readings climbed into the mid and upper 90s each day. Little mixing of dew points occurred each day, which when combined with these hot temperatures, resulted in oppressively hot conditions as heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees across Southwest Arkansas. The heat wave continued into the first day of August before ending on August 2nd as a weak cool front and scattered showers and thunderstorms moved through the region.

Upper-level high pressure parked over the region resulting in a period of unseasonably hot weather across the Mid-South during the end of July. High temperatures combined with high humidity to produce afternoon heat index values of 105 degrees or higher.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105 to 110 degrees in the afternoon and early evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms developed along a stalled frontal boundary during the afternoon hours of Wednesday, July 7th, 2021. Several reports of downed trees and wires resulted from the severe storms. A microburst was confirmed in Columbia and Greene Counties where an estimated 70 to 90 mph winds caused significant damage in the towns of Coxsackie and Stuyvesant. A state of emergency was declared in the town of Coxsackie as a result of the damage. ||A second round of severe thunderstorms moved into eastern New York during the late evening of the 7th into the early morning of the 8th with a few reports of downed trees.||Additionally, heat indices across the mid-Hudson Valley and southern Taconics exceeded 95 degrees during the afternoon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge supported a heat wave over northern California during this interval.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On 08/10/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 56 to 57 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 100 to 102 degrees. On 08/11/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 57 to 60 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 104 to 108 degrees. On 08/12/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 62 to 65 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 103 to 104 degrees. On 08/13/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 66 to 66 degrees and the reported high temperatures ranged from 99 to 103 degrees. On 08/14/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 64 to 65 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 101 to 104 degrees. On 08/15/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 65 to 68 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 103 to 105 degrees. On 08/15/21, Montague recorded a high temperature of 105 degrees, tying the record high for that date.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably hot temperatures occurred in advance of a slow moving cold front. High temperatures across portions of west-central and Downeast Maine ranged from around 90 to the mid 90s...with dewpoints of around 70 to the lower 70s. Apparent temperatures generally ranged from the upper 90s to around 105.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Apparent temperatures ranged from the upper 90s to around 105 degrees.

Hot weather began to develop August 9, peaking August 11-12, but temperatures continued above normal into the weekend. Peak afternoon temperatures of 100 to 105 degrees drove people to seek relief in or near bodies of water. Heat caused slowdowns on the MAX light rail (Portland metro area) systems, and some businesses did close due to the heat. Cooling shelters were opened in several counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Dee Flat agrimet station (DEFO) reported a high temperature of 101 degrees on the 11th and 97 degrees on the 12th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet sensor (C4896) near Walterville reported high temperature of 100 degrees on the 11th and 101 degrees on the 12th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge supported a heat wave over inland areas of southwest and south central Oregon during this interval.

On 08/11/21, the reported low temperature was 57 degrees and the high was 92 degrees. On 08/12/21, the reported low temperature was 58 degrees and the high was 87 degrees. On 08/13/21, the reported low temperature was 59 degrees and the high was 82 degrees. On 08/14/21, the reported low temperature was 58 degrees and the high was 87 degrees. On 08/15/21, the reported low temperature was 61 degrees and the high was 89 degrees.

A high pressure heat dome over the region led to stretch of extreme heat, shattering records from June 26 through June 29. Hot temperatures resulted in many people seeking locations to cool off in local rivers and beaches, which led to one drowning, as well as multiple people going to local hospitals for treatment of typical heat-related medical symptoms, including one reported death.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures. There were three consecutive days with maximum temperatures greater than 100 degrees. Maximum temperatures were around 108 degrees on June 27 and June 28. There was one death reported due to heat related illness.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Twin 3-year-old boys went missing the afternoon of Monday the 9th in to city of Hibbing. Police were dispatched around 5:30PM to search for the boys who were found an hour later in a locked vehicle near their residence. Both boys were unresponsive and in medical distress when found. After being transported to a local hospital, one of the boys was airlifted to a children's specialty hospital in Minneapolis, Minnesota, where he later died. The other boy was treated and released.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twin 3-year-old boys were reported missing around 5:30PM the afternoon of the 9th in Hibbing, Minnesota. Officers and neighbors searched for the boys who were located around 6:30PM locked inside a vehicle. Both of the boys were unresponsive and in medical distress when found. Air temperatures at the time were in the middle 80s, but inside the car it was in excess of 120F. One of the boys was airlifted to a children's specialty hospital in Minneapolis, Minnesota, where he later died. The other boy was treated and released from a local hospital.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid air mass developed ahead of an approaching cold front across eastern New York on Thursday, August 26, 2021. Heat indices reached 95 to 101 degrees across most areas outside of the higher elevations during the afternoon hours.||The cold front slowly dropped southward during the day on Friday, August 27, 2021, but heat indices still reached 95 to 100 degrees across portions of the mid-Hudson Valley during the afternoon prior to the frontal passage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot weather began to develop August 9, peaking August 11-12, but temperatures continued above normal into the weekend. Peak afternoon temperatures of 100 to 105 degrees drove people to seek relief in or near bodies of water. Heat caused slowdowns on the MAX light rail (Portland metro area) systems, and some businesses did close due to the heat. Cooling shelters were opened in several counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The high temperatures near Rainier (ODT93) was 100 degrees on the 11th and 12th.

A strong upper level ridge of high pressure and a surface thermal trough brought several days of record high temperatures across the PacNW, with many locations in the lower and higher elevations experiencing extreme heat risk during this event. The multiple days of extreme heat risk has been attributed to several fatalities across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Calculated heat risk values at the Whitman Mission, WA station recorded consecutive days between June 29th through July 1st of temperatures that met or exceeded excessive heat warning criteria.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Roberts Butte RAWS recorded consecutive daily high temperatures over 95 degrees from June 27th through July 1st, with many daily high temperatures even meeting or exceeding 100 degrees during the period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours of Tuesday, July 6th, 2021, as an upper level disturbance tracked through the region. Several downed trees and wires resulted from the strongest storms. More than 25,000 customers lost power.||Additionally, heat indices across southern Litchfield county exceeded 95 degrees during the afternoon hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere developed over the south central United States during late July. Afternoon temperatures reaching the upper 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with high humidity, resulted in daily heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across portions of eastern Oklahoma from the 24th through the 31st. At least 45 heat-related medical calls occurred during this period in Tulsa County.

The heat wave continued through the morning of the 30th and then further intensified through the afternoon of the 30th into the first day of August before finally ending on August 2nd as a weak cool front and scattered showers and thunderstorms moved through the region.

Bermuda high pressure and upper level ridging resulted in excessive heat and humidity across the region. Excessive moisture from the nearby Chesapeake Bay resulted in heat indices between 105 and 110 across southern Maryland.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices reached 105-110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several days of oppressive heat created hazardous conditions. From the 24th to the 29th, heat indices peaked above 100 degrees each afternoon. At the Carbondale airport, the highest heat index of this multi-day period was 109 degrees on the 25th. A very persistent area of high pressure centered over the Appalachian Mountains produced a long duration of hot and humid south winds.

Upper level ridging built back in over the Ark-La-Tex during the second week of August, resulting in a return of afternoon temperatures back into the mid and upper 90s across East Texas. Southerly winds maintained the very humid conditions in place, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees across portions of East Texas, mainly counties bordering the Red River, the Louisiana state line, as well as much of Deep East Texas from August 9th-12th. A weak frontal system and associated showers and thunderstorms moved into the region on the 13th, bringing about several days of needed rainfall and cooler temperatures.

The typical summertime upper level ridge built in across the region, resulting in Heat Index values between 105-110 degrees across mainly the northeastern half of the CWA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat Index values reached 105-110 degrees in the afternoon hours of the 25th and 26th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a brief reprieve, the summertime upper level ridge built back across the region, resulting in Heat Index values between 105-110 degrees across most of North and Central Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat Index values reached 105-110 degrees in the afternoon hours of the 29th through 31st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere developed over the south central United States during late July. Afternoon temperatures reaching the upper 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with high humidity, resulted in daily heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across portions of eastern Oklahoma from the 24th through the 31st. At least 45 heat-related medical calls occurred during this period in Tulsa County.

Temperatures and humidity rose at the end of July to produce heat indices ranging from 105 to 113. The highest values were generally across southern Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices across the county varied from 105 to 111 throughout the period. Chanute Martin Johnson Airport had a calculated heat index of 110 on the 28th and 111 on the 31st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures and humidity rose at the end of July to produce heat indices ranging from 105 to 113. The highest values were generally across southern Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices across the county varied from 106 to 110 throughout the period. Coffeyville Airport reported a heat index of 110 on the 27th and 31st. Independence Airport reported a heat index of 110 on the 31st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level ridging strengthened over the Mid-South late in July as dewpoints surged to near 80 degrees across parts of the region. High temperatures combined with the high dewpoints to produce heat index values of 110 degrees or higher.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 110 degrees or higher in the afternoon and early evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A high pressure heat dome over the region led to stretch of extreme heat, shattering records from June 26 through June 29. Hot temperatures resulted in many people seeking locations to cool off in local rivers and beaches, which led to one drowning, as well as multiple people going to local hospitals for treatment of typical heat-related medical symptoms, including one reported death.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Record breaking temperatures for 3 days in a row. Vancouver (KVUO) recorded high temperatures of 108, 112, and 115 F. Three heat related deaths were reported in Clark County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of an abnormally strong ridge and dry soil produced very hot temperatures in many areas. The hottest temperature during the period was 107 degrees at Greybull on July 19th. Record high temperatures were also recorded at Worland, Riverton, Lander, Buffalo, Rock Springs, and Big Piney.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Record high temperatures of 104 and 107 were recorded at South Big Horn County Airport  on July 18th and 19th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of an abnormally strong ridge and dry soil produced very hot temperatures in many areas. The hottest temperature during the period was 107 degrees at Greybull on July 19th. Record high temperatures were also recorded at Worland, Riverton, Lander, Buffalo, Rock Springs, and Big Piney.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A record high temperature of 106 degrees was recorded at Worland Municipal Airport on July 18th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A high pressure heat dome over the region led to stretch of extreme heat, shattering records from June 26 through June 29. Hot temperatures resulted in many people seeking locations to cool off in local rivers and beaches, which led to one drowning, as well as multiple people going to local hospitals for treatment of typical heat-related medical symptoms, including one reported death.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A reliable SkyWarn spotter (Pacific-34) called to report his temperature sensor was recording 105 degrees. A middle-aged man drowned on Sunday, June 27.

Upper level ridging built back in over the Ark-La-Tex during the second week of August, resulting in a return of afternoon temperatures back into the mid and upper 90s across North Louisiana. Southerly winds maintained the very humid conditions in place, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-107 degrees from August 9th-12th. A weak frontal system and associated showers and thunderstorms moved into the region on the 13th, bringing about several days of needed rainfall and cooler temperatures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere developed over the south central United States during late July. Afternoon temperatures reaching the upper 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with high humidity, resulted in daily heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across west central Arkansas from the 25th through the 31st.

Afternoon temperatures reaching the upper 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with high humidity, resulted in daily heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across west central Arkansas from the 25th through the 31st.
Temperatures and humidity rose at the end of July to produce heat indices ranging from 105 to 113. The highest values were generally across southern Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices across the county varied from 105 to 110 throughout the period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of an abnormally strong ridge and dry soil produced very hot temperatures in many areas. The hottest temperature during the period was 107 degrees at Greybull on July 19th. Record high temperatures were also recorded at Worland, Riverton, Lander, Buffalo, Rock Springs, and Big Piney.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A record high temperature of 100 degrees was reported at Central Wyoming Regional Airport on July 18th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Record high temperatures of 98 and 101 were set the the Johnson County Airport on July 17th and 19th, respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level ridging strengthened over the Mid-South late in July as dewpoints surged to near 80 degrees across parts of the region. High temperatures combined with the high dewpoints to produce heat index values of 110 degrees or higher.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 110 degrees or higher in the afternoon and early evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure was anchored from Nebraska/Kansas southeast into portions of the Lower Mississippi Valley from July 30th through the end of the month, resulting in very hot temperatures across the Ark-La-Tex as readings climbed into the mid and upper 90s each day. Little mixing of dew points occurred each day, which when combined with these hot temperatures, resulted in oppressively hot conditions as heat indices ranged from 110-115 degrees each day across much of Northcentral Louisiana. The heat wave continued through the first day of August before finally ending on August 2nd as a weak cool front and scattered showers and thunderstorms moved through the region.

A hot and humid air mass developed ahead of an approaching cold front across eastern New York on Thursday, August 26, 2021. Heat indices reached 95 to 101 degrees across most areas outside of the higher elevations during the afternoon hours.||The cold front slowly dropped southward during the day on Friday, August 27, 2021, but heat indices still reached 95 to 100 degrees across portions of the mid-Hudson Valley during the afternoon prior to the frontal passage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere developed over the south central United States during late July. Afternoon temperatures reaching the upper 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with high humidity, resulted in daily heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across west central Arkansas from the 25th through the 31st.
An active monsoon surge brought several back-to-back days of thunderstorms producing heavy rain, damaging wind gusts, and hail across the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 9-year-old boy was found dead in a vehicle in American Fork on Wednesday, July 21, at around 1:45 p.m. It is believed the child was inside the car for approximately two hours before he was discovered. Temperatures in the vicinity of American Fork at the time were generally in the 90-95 degree Fahrenheit range.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of an abnormally strong ridge and dry soil produced very hot temperatures in many areas. The hottest temperature during the period was 107 degrees at Greybull on July 19th. Record high temperatures were also recorded at Worland, Riverton, Lander, Buffalo, Rock Springs, and Big Piney.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At the Southwest Wyoming Regional Airport east of Rock Springs, record high temperatures of 94 and 96 were recorded on July 18th and 19th, respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of an abnormally strong ridge and dry soil produced very hot temperatures in many areas. The hottest temperature during the period was 107 degrees at Greybull on July 19th. Record high temperatures were also recorded at Worland, Riverton, Lander, Buffalo, Rock Springs, and Big Piney.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Record high temperatures of 92 and 94 were set at the Big Piney-Marbleton Airport on July 18th and 19th, respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very strong ridge over the northern Rockies brought record high temperatures to much of western and central Wyoming. The highest temperature was 106 degrees at Worland on July 27th. High temperatures over 100 degrees were recorded at many locations east of the Continental Divide during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Record high temperatures of 102 and 105 were recorded at South Big Horn County Airport on July 26th and 27th, respectively.

The highest temperature was 106 degrees at Worland on July 27th. High temperatures over 100 degrees were recorded at many locations east of the Continental Divide during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A record high temperature of 106 was recorded at Worland Municipal Airport on July 27th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very strong ridge over the northern Rockies brought record high temperatures to much of western and central Wyoming. The highest temperature was 106 degrees at Worland on July 27th. High temperatures over 100 degrees were recorded at many locations east of the Continental Divide during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The recorded high temperature at Central Wyoming Regional Airport set a record three days in a row. Record high temperatures of 96, 97 and 100 were recorded on July 25th, 26th and 27th, respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot weather began to develop August 9, peaking August 11-12, but temperatures continued above normal into the weekend. Peak afternoon temperatures of 100 to 105 degrees drove people to seek relief in or near bodies of water. Heat caused slowdowns on the MAX light rail (Portland metro area) systems, and some businesses did close due to the heat. Cooling shelters were opened in several counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperature in the lower elevations of area was around 100 degrees on the 11th and 12th. The high temperature near Blue River (OD159) along the McKenzie Highway was 104 degrees on the 11th and 102 degrees on the 12th.

The heat wave continued through the first day of August before finally ending on August 2nd as a weak cool front and scattered showers and thunderstorms moved through the region.

An upper level ridge of high pressure was anchored from Nebraska/Kansas southeast into portions of the Lower Mississippi Valley from July 30th through the end of the month, resulting in very hot temperatures across the Ark-La-Tex as readings climbed into the mid and upper 90s each day. Little mixing of dew points occurred each day, which when combined with these hot temperatures, resulted in oppressively hot conditions as heat indices ranged from 110-115 degrees each day across much of Northcentral Louisiana. The heat wave continued through the first day of August before finally ending on August 2nd as a weak cool front and scattered showers and thunderstorms moved through the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several days of oppressive heat created hazardous conditions. From the 24th to the 29th, heat indices peaked above 100 degrees each afternoon. At the Paducah airport, the highest heat index of this multi-day period was 104 degrees on the 26th. The highest heat index during this heat wave at Princeton was 105 degrees. A very persistent area of high pressure centered over the Appalachian Mountains produced a long duration of hot and humid south winds.

A very persistent area of high pressure centered over the Appalachian Mountains produced a long duration of hot and humid south winds.

Upper level ridging built back in over the Ark-La-Tex during the second week of August, resulting in a return of afternoon temperatures back into the mid and upper 90s across North Louisiana. Southerly winds maintained the very humid conditions in place, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-107 degrees from August 9th-12th. A weak frontal system and associated showers and thunderstorms moved into the region on the 13th, bringing about several days of needed rainfall and cooler temperatures.

Unseasonably hot temperatures and high dewpoints persisted for a second day in advance of a slow moving cold front. Several locations reported record high low temperatures. Temperatures ranged from around 90 to the mid 90s...with dewpoints from around 70 to the lower 70s. Apparent temperatures ranged from the mid 90s to around 100.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Apparent temperatures ranged through the 90s to around 100.

Temperatures ranged from around 90 to the lower 90s...with dewpoints from the upper 60s to around 70. Apparent temperatures ranged from the mid 90s to around 100.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Apparent temperatures ranged from the mid 90s to around 100.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very strong ridge over the northern Rockies brought record high temperatures to much of western and central Wyoming. The highest temperature was 106 degrees at Worland on July 27th. High temperatures over 100 degrees were recorded at many locations east of the Continental Divide during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Johnson County Airport in Buffalo set record highs three days in a row. Record high temperatures of 97, 97 and 102 were recorded on July 25th, 26th and 27th, respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very strong ridge over the northern Rockies brought record high temperatures to much of western and central Wyoming. The highest temperature was 106 degrees at Worland on July 27th. High temperatures over 100 degrees were recorded at many locations east of the Continental Divide during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daily high temperatures at Southwest Wyoming Regional Airport set records on July 26th and 27th. High temperatures of 93 and 92 were recorded, respectively.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A record high temperature of 100 degrees was set at Casper-Natrona County International Airport just west of Casper.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The thermometer hit a new record high temperature of 98 degrees at Hunt Field in Lander July 26th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot weather began to develop August 9, peaking August 11-12, but temperatures continued above normal into the weekend. Peak afternoon temperatures of 100 to 105 degrees drove people to seek relief in or near bodies of water. Heat caused slowdowns on the MAX light rail (Portland metro area) systems, and some businesses did close due to the heat. Cooling shelters were opened in several counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 61-year-old man drowned while swimming at Hagg Lake on Saturday August 14th, according to the Washington County Sheriffs Office. The sheriffs office responded to reports of a swimmer who had gone under water. The high temperature at Hagg lake was 92 degrees on the 14th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot weather began to develop August 9, peaking August 11-12, but temperatures continued above normal into the weekend. Peak afternoon temperatures of 100 to 105 degrees drove people to seek relief in or near bodies of water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The RAWS at Dodson (DSRO3) reported 98 degrees on the 11th and 105 on the 12th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Hood River, at the Ken Jernstedt Airfield (K4S2), it was 104 degrees on the 11th and 102 degrees on the 12th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The high temperature at Vancouver (KVUO) was 101 degrees on the 11th and 103 degrees on the 12th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot weather began to develop August 9, peaking August 11-12, but temperatures continued above normal into the weekend. Peak afternoon temperatures of 100 to 105 degrees drove people to seek relief in or near bodies of water. Heat caused slowdowns on the MAX light rail (Portland metro area) systems, and some businesses did close due to the heat. Cooling shelters were opened in several counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 22-year-old California man drowned at Scotts Mill City Park in Marion County Wednesday, August 11th. Deputies say children were swimming in the water at the base of the falls around 3 p.m. when they spotted what appeared to be a man underneath the water.  Clackamas County Sheriffs Office Dive Team responded to the scene and recovered the body of an adult male. He was found in approximately eight feet of water directly below the falls. The high temperature at Salem (KSLE) was 103 degrees on the 11th and 12th.

Upper-level high pressure parked over the region resulting in a period of unseasonably hot weather across the Mid-South during the end of July. High temperatures combined with high humidity to produce afternoon heat index values of 105 degrees or higher.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105 to 110 degrees in the afternoon and early evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot weather began to develop August 9, peaking August 11-12, but temperatures continued above normal into the weekend. Peak afternoon temperatures of 100 to 105 degrees drove people to seek relief in or near bodies of water. Heat caused slowdowns on the MAX light rail (Portland metro area) systems, and some businesses did close due to the heat. Cooling shelters were opened in several counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The high temperature in the lower elevations of the Cascades was around 100 degrees on the 11th and 12th.  A sensor on Highway 26 at ZigZag (OD165) reported high temperature of 96 degrees on the 11th and 104 degrees on the 12th. Along highway 22 at Detroit, it was 105 degrees on the 11th and 104 degrees on the 12th as reported by the Detroit Lake agrimet (DTRO). The heat continued in this area until the 13th with a high temperature of 100 degrees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eagle Creek RAWS (EGKO3) reported high temperature of 101 degrees on the 11th and 12th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several days of oppressive heat created hazardous conditions. From the 24th to the 29th, heat indices peaked above 100 degrees each afternoon. At the Carbondale airport, the highest heat index of this multi-day period was 109 degrees on the 25th. A very persistent area of high pressure centered over the Appalachian Mountains produced a long duration of hot and humid south winds.

Upper level ridging built back in over the Ark-La-Tex during the second week of August, resulting in a return of afternoon temperatures back into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees across Southwest Arkansas. Southerly winds maintained the very humid conditions in place, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-108 degrees from August 9th-12th. A weak frontal system and associated showers and thunderstorms moved into the region on the 13th, bringing about several days of needed rainfall and cooler temperatures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of high pressure continued to stay centered to the west of New Mexico which led to well above normal temperatures across western portions of the state on July 10, 2021. The Farmington Airport recorded a high temperature of 106 degrees Fahrenheit which broke their all-time record high temperature. This also met criteria for excessive heat as this was the second consecutive day with temperatures of at least 105 degrees Fahrenheit. Meanwhile, a backdoor cold front that moved into eastern New Mexico early in the day provided an increase in low-level moisture and instability which allowed for an increase in storm coverage across the plains. A few of these thunderstorms became strong to severe with reports of large hail and severe winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Farmington Airport recorded a high temperature of 106 degrees Fahrenheit which set a new all-time record high temperature for the locations. This was also the second consecutive day of high temperatures of at least 105 degrees which met excessive heat criteria for the Northwest Plateau.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure originating from the four-corners region built westward into California resulting in very hot daytime temperatures and warm overnight low temperatures across interior Northern California. High to very high heat risk impacted the region with a several day heatwave. One daily high temperature record was tied and one daily high temperature record was broken. During the event, cooling centers were made available to the public across interior Northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake Shasta Dam saw high temperatures reach 107 to 112 degrees during the event.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Over 50 heat related illnesses were reported across the Oklahoma City area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level high pressure strengthened over the Mid-South around mid-August resulting in hot and humid conditions. Afternoon heat index values greater than 105 degrees were widespread across the Mid-South.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105 to 110 degrees in the afternoon and early evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced in much of southeast Arizona from June 12-20 with high temperatures exceeding established records in many locations. A number of  heat-related deaths were reported of persons found in desert.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot high temperatures of 106 to 119 degrees, or 8 to 13 degrees above normal, occurred in the lower elevations of southeast Arizona June 12-20, and caused the High Heat Risk category to be reached. New record daily high temperature records were established at numerous sites on several days during this period. For Tucson International Airport, this nine day period contributed to the hottest June on record and the 4th hottest temperature on record of 115 degrees occurred on June 15.  Sites that tied or broke all time hottest temperature records included Ajo with 119 degrees, Sasabe with 113, Green Valley with 112. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for 14 people found in the desert of Pima and Santa Cruz counties during this time period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced in much of southeast Arizona from June 12-20 with high temperatures exceeding established records in many locations. A number of  heat-related deaths were reported of persons found in desert.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A man on a four-day hike suffered heat exhaustion in the Santa Catalina Mountains.  He had checked in the morning of his passing but did not make it to his pick up point. High temperatures were above normal and ranged from 90 to 100 degrees between 5000 and 7000 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures in the 100s occurred on June 27 on the Tohono O'odham Nation. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three persons found in the desert.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures 5 to 10 degrees above normal, from 104 to 108, occurred on the Tohono O'odham Nation causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached on June 27. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two males and one female found in different locations of the desert.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures topping out from 95 to 100 degrees were experienced on June 10 in mid slope areas of Santa Cruz County. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one male found in the Patagonia Mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures of 95 to 100 degrees, or 4 to 8 degrees above normal occurred on June 10 in mid slope areas of Santa Cruz County, causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one male found in the Patagonia Mountains.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot high temperatures of 103 to 112 degrees, or 8 to 16 degrees above normal, occurred in the lower elevations of Cochise County June 12-14, and caused the High Heat Risk category to be reached. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The fifth Santa Ana wind episode of the season and record heat were recorded November 11-16. Also, widespread dense fog was reported across coastal San Diego County on November 15. A brush fire was reported near Desert Hot Springs in the early morning hours on November 11.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two sites in Orange County broke their daily high temperature record on November 11. Anaheim reached a high temperature of 95 degrees, breaking the old record of 92 set in 1990. Santa Ana recorded a high temperature of 92 degrees, breaking the old record of 90 set in 1986.||Santa Ana recorded a record-breaking high temperature for the second day in a row; it reached a high temperature of 96 degrees, breaking the previous record of 92 degrees set in 1974. Several sites in Orange County broke their overnight highest minimum temperature that day as well, including Newport Beach (65 degrees) and Santa Ana (69 degrees).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The fifth Santa Ana wind episode of the season and record heat were recorded November 11-16. Also, widespread dense fog was reported across coastal San Diego County on November 15. A brush fire was reported near Desert Hot Springs in the early morning hours on November 11.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ramona broke the daily high temperature record on November 11, reaching a high of 91 degrees, breaking the previous record of 87 set in 2016.||Ramona broke the daily high temperature record on November 14, reaching 92 degrees, breaking the previous record of 90 set in 2007.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The fifth Santa Ana wind episode of the season and record heat were recorded November 11-16. Also, widespread dense fog was reported across coastal San Diego County on November 15. A brush fire was reported near Desert Hot Springs in the early morning hours on November 11.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thermal tied the high temperature record for November 11, reaching a high of 92 degrees, tying the previous record set in 1973. Three sites in the Coachella Valley broke their highest minimum temperature record for November; Palm Springs recorded a low temperature of 69 degrees, breaking the previous record of 65 degrees set in 1934; Indio recorded a low of 69, breaking the previous record of 65 set in 1988; Borrego recorded a low of 63 degrees, breaking the previous record of 62 set in 2003.||Palm Springs broke the daily high temperature record for November 14 reaching a high of 93 degrees, breaking the previous record of 92 degrees set in 2007.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Santa Ana Winds and dense fog were reported November 20-22.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Newport Beach broke the high temperature record for November 21, reaching a high of 85 degrees, breaking the previous record of 84 degrees set in 1998.

CZ_NAME: EASTERN SAN JOAQUIN VALLEY IN KERN COUNTY
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of high pressure which had been centered over the Great Basin built westward into central California on August 14 and brought dangerous heat to portions of the central California interior between August 14 and August 16. Several stations in the Kern County Deserts had afternoon highs at 110 Degrees F or higher each day between August 14 and August 16. Hot daytime temperatures were also common throughout the San Joaquin Valley and West Side Hills where afternoon highs around 105 Degrees F were common. The high began to weaken on August 17 and daytime temperatures trended lower. By August 18, temperatures across the area were close to their seasonal normals.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 102 and 106 degrees between August 14 and August 16.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Three to four days of oppressive heat created hazardous conditions. From the 9th to the 12th, heat indices peaked at or above 105 degrees each afternoon. The oppressive heat actually started on the 10th in the Henderson/Owensboro area and adjacent counties. At the Paducah airport, the highest heat index of this multi-day period was 105 degrees on the 10th. The highest heat index during this heat wave at Princeton was 108 degrees. A rather strong southwest wind flow of hot and humid air prevailed between a slow-moving cold front over the Plains and a stationary high pressure center near the Carolina coast.

An upper level ridge of high pressure was anchored from Nebraska/Kansas southeast across portions of the Lower Mississippi Valley through August 1st, resulting in very hot temperatures across the Ark-La-Tex as readings climbed into the mid and upper 90s. Very little mixing of dew points occurred throughout the day, which when combined with these hot temperatures, resulted in oppressively hot conditions as heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees across much of East and Northeast Texas. The heat wave finally ended on August 2nd as a weak cool front and scattered showers and thunderstorms moved through the region.

An upper level ridge of high pressure was centered over the Ark-La-Tex throughout the third and fourth weeks of August, before expanding east into the Mississippi Valley. This resulted in temperatures climbing into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees across much of North Louisiana from August 21st-26th, with little mixing of dew points observed during the period. As a result, heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees each day across North Louisiana, before the ridge aloft weakened by the 27th, with slightly lower temperatures and heat indices observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure over the southwestern US strengthened over central California on August 28 and brought widespread dangerous heat to the area on August 29 and 30.  High temperatures exceeded 110 degrees F across much of the Kern County Deserts on August 29 and 30 and exceeded 105 degrees F across much of the San Joaquin Valley and West Side Hills.  The high weakened on August 31 as a upper trough pushed into the Pacific Northwest resulting in a cooling trend across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 103 and 108 degrees on August 29 and August 30.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure over the southwestern US strengthened over central California on August 28 and brought widespread dangerous heat to the area on August 29 and 30.  High temperatures exceeded 110 degrees F across much of the Kern County Deserts on August 29 and 30 and exceeded 105 degrees F across much of the San Joaquin Valley and West Side Hills.  The high weakened on August 31 as a upper trough pushed into the Pacific Northwest resulting in a cooling trend across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 103 and 108 degrees on August 29 and August 30.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Three to four days of oppressive heat created hazardous conditions. From the 9th to the 12th, heat indices peaked at or above 105 degrees each afternoon. The oppressive heat actually started on the 10th in the Henderson/Owensboro area and adjacent counties. At the Paducah airport, the highest heat index of this multi-day period was 105 degrees on the 10th. The highest heat index during this heat wave at Princeton was 108 degrees. A rather strong southwest wind flow of hot and humid air prevailed between a slow-moving cold front over the Plains and a stationary high pressure center near the Carolina coast.

An upper level ridge of high pressure was anchored from Nebraska/Kansas southeast across portions of the Lower Mississippi Valley through August 1st, resulting in very hot temperatures across the Ark-La-Tex as readings climbed into the mid and upper 90s. Very little mixing of dew points occurred throughout the day, which when combined with these hot temperatures, resulted in oppressively hot conditions as heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees across much of East and Northeast Texas. The heat wave finally ended on August 2nd as a weak cool front and scattered showers and thunderstorms moved through the region.

An upper level ridge of high pressure was centered over the Ark-La-Tex throughout the third and fourth weeks of August, before expanding east into the Mississippi Valley. This resulted in temperatures climbing into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees across much of North Louisiana from August 21st-26th, with little mixing of dew points observed during the period. As a result, heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees each day across North Louisiana, before the ridge aloft weakened by the 27th, with slightly lower temperatures and heat indices observed.

An upper level ridge of high pressure was centered over the Ark-La-Tex throughout the third and fourth weeks of August, before expanding east into the Mississippi Valley. This resulted in temperatures climbing into the mid to upper 90s across Union, Ouachita, and Caldwell Parishes from August 21st-22nd, with little mixing of dew points observed during the period. As a result, heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees each day across these areas, before hotter conditions were observed resulting in higher heat indices in excess of 110 degrees on the 23rd. Thus, the Heat Advisory was upgrading to an Excessive Heat Warning for the 23rd.

An upper level ridge of high pressure was centered over the Ark-La-Tex throughout the third and fourth weeks of August, before expanding east into the Mississippi Valley. This resulted in temperatures climbing into the mid to upper 90s across Union, Ouachita, and Caldwell Parishes from August 21st-22nd, with little mixing of dew points observed during the period. An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded east into the Mississippi Valley on August 23rd, resulting in temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across Union, Ouachita, and Caldwell Parishes through the 24th. Little mixing of dew points were observed during this period, with heat indices climbing in excess of 110 degrees over these areas. The ridge weakened slightly on the 25th and 26th, resulting in slightly cooler temperatures in the mid 90s and thus, produced lower heat indices between 105-110 degrees. The Excessive Heat Warning was downgraded to a Heat Advisory for these areas during the evening of August 24th.

The upper level ridge of high pressure weakened slightly over the Mississippi Valley late on August 24th through the 26th, resulting in temperatures falling slightly to the mid 90s across Union, Ouachita, and Caldwell Parishes. Little mixing of dew points continued during this period, with heat indices still ranging from 105-110 degrees over these areas. With the weakening ridge aloft during the final week of August, scattered showers and thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and spread west-southwest over North Louisiana, providing some relief to the extreme heat.

The upper level ridge of high pressure weakened slightly over the Mississippi Valley late on August 24th through the 26th, resulting in temperatures falling slightly to the mid 90s across Union, Ouachita, and Caldwell Parishes. Little mixing of dew points continued during this period, with heat indices still ranging from 105-110 degrees over these areas. With the weakening ridge aloft during the final week of August, scattered showers and thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and spread west-southwest over North Louisiana, providing some relief to the extreme heat.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Four days of oppressive heat created hazardous conditions. From the 9th to the 12th, heat indices peaked at or above 105 degrees each afternoon. At the Cape Girardeau airport, the highest heat index of this multi-day period was 106 degrees on the 11th and 12th. The highest heat index during this heat wave at Poplar Bluff was 108 degrees. A rather strong southwest wind flow of hot and humid air prevailed between a slow-moving cold front over the Plains and a stationary high pressure center near the Carolina coast.

Four days of oppressive heat created hazardous conditions. From the 9th to the 12th, heat indices peaked at or above 105 degrees each afternoon. At the Cape Girardeau airport, the highest heat index of this multi-day period was 106 degrees on the 11th and 12th. The highest heat index during this heat wave at Poplar Bluff was 108 degrees. A rather strong southwest wind flow of hot and humid air prevailed between a slow-moving cold front over the Plains and a stationary high pressure center near the Carolina coast.

An upper level ridge of high pressure was anchored from Nebraska/Kansas southeast across portions of the Lower Mississippi Valley through August 1st, resulting in very hot temperatures across the Ark-La-Tex as readings climbed into the mid and upper 90s. Very little mixing of dew points occurred throughout the day, which when combined with these hot temperatures, resulted in oppressively hot conditions as heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees across much of Northwest and North-central Louisiana. The heat wave finally ended on August 2nd as a weak cool front and scattered showers and thunderstorms moved through the region.

A dome of high pressure settled across eastern New York from Wednesday, August 11 to Friday, August 13 bringing high heat and humidity each day, mainly during the afternoon hours. A strong ridge supported a heat wave over inland areas of southwest and south central Oregon during this interval.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On 08/10/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 52 to 58 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 94 to 101 degrees. On 08/11/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 53 to 64 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 97 to 105 degrees. On 08/12/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 58 to 67 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 101 to 106 degrees. On 08/13/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 57 to 70 degrees and the reported high temperatures ranged from 87 to 103 degrees. On 08/14/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 56 to 66 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 94 to 97 degrees. On 08/15/21, the reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 56 to 66 degrees and the high temperatures ranged from 84 to 100 degrees. The Roseburg airport recorded a high temperature of 98 degrees on 08/10/21, setting a new record high for that date. The old record was 97 degrees, set in 2014.

High dewpoint temperatures combined with very hot daytime high temperatures on August 18th, resulting in heat index values in excess of 111 degrees for Starr and Hidalgo County during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The McAllen Airport ASOS site first recorded heat index values reaching or exceeding 111 degrees around 2:30 PM CDT. Heat index values then remained above 111 degrees through 5:30 PM, topping out around 112 degrees during this time. Edinburg International Airport also observed heat index values of 111 degrees at least intermittently during this time. No heat-related injuries or fatalities were reported as of this writing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High dewpoint temperatures combined with very hot daytime high temperatures on August 18th, resulting in heat index values in excess of 111 degrees for Starr and Hidalgo County during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This event is based largely on observed heat index values across Southern Hidalgo county and also across Zapata County, the latter of which saw heat indices top out at 112 degrees but only lasting for about an hour. Given the higher heat index values in Hidalgo/Zapata counties, it is inferred that Starr County also experienced heat index values in excess of 111 degrees for at least two hours. The Falcon Lake RAWS site recorded values technically reaching Excessive Heat criteria, but this observation site has a history of running notably higher than surrounding areas. No heat-related injuries or fatalities were reported as of this writing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Three to four days of oppressive heat created hazardous conditions. From the 10th to the 12th, heat indices peaked at or above 105 degrees each afternoon. The oppressive heat started on the 9th along and west of a line from Mount Vernon to Metropolis. At the Carbondale airport, the highest heat index of this multi-day period was 108 degrees on the 10th. A rather strong southwest wind flow of hot and humid air prevailed between a slow-moving cold front over the Plains and a stationary high pressure center near the Carolina coast.

Upper level ridging built back in over the Ark-La-Tex during the second week of August, resulting in a return of afternoon temperatures back into the mid and upper 90s across Southeast Oklahoma. Southerly winds maintained the very humid conditions in place, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across McCurtain County from August 9th-12th. A weak frontal system and associated showers and thunderstorms moved into the region on the 13th, bringing about several days of needed rainfall and cooler temperatures.

An upper level ridge of high pressure was centered over the Ark-La-Tex throughout the third and fourth weeks of August, before expanding east into the Mississippi Valley. This resulted in temperatures climbing into the mid 90s across Southeast Oklahoma from August 21st-26th, with little mixing of dew points observed during the period. As a result, heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees each day across McCurtain County, before the ridge aloft weakened by the 27th, with slightly lower temperatures and heat indices observed.

An upper level ridge of high pressure was centered over the Ark-La-Tex throughout the third and fourth weeks of August, before expanding east into the Mississippi Valley. This resulted in temperatures climbing into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees across Southwest Arkansas from August 21st-26th, with little mixing of dew points observed during the period. As a result, heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees each day across Southwest Arkansas, before the ridge aloft weakened by the 27th, with slightly lower temperatures and heat indices observed.

As a result, heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees each day across Southwest Arkansas, before the ridge aloft weakened by the 27th, with slightly lower temperatures and heat indices observed.

A dome of high pressure settled across eastern New York from Wednesday, August 11 to Friday, August 13 bringing high heat and humidity each day, mainly during the afternoon hours. Heat indices reached 95 to 104 degrees across parts of the area each of these days with areas along the Hudson River from Albany and points southward reaching 105 to 110 on Thursday, August 12. The Hudson Valley Regional Airport recorded an official heat wave with high temperatures all three days in the low to mid-90s.

Upper-level high pressure prevailed across the region resulting in high heat and humidity. Heat index values at 105 degrees and greater were widespread across the St. Louis metro area from August 10th through 12th.  Due to 4 days of heat index values at 105 degrees or greater (August 9th through 12th), an Excessive Heat Warning was issued.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values were in excess of 105 degrees for a 4 day stretch across the St. Louis Metro area.

A strong upper level ridge of high pressure began to build into the region around August 11, remaining in place through August 13 before pushing eastward. As the upper level ridge influence increased over the region, the lower level flow turned easterly, creating a downsloping effect across much of Western Washington. As a result of this setup, very warm temperatures were forecast for most of the area, with 850mb temperatures expected to peak near 25C during the heart of the event, with surface temperatures ranging from the mid 80s to near 100 and low temperatures during the overnight period ranging from the mid 60s to low 70s.||Excessive Heat Watch was issued on August 8, several days prior to the event, valid for all included zones beginning 12PM on Wednesday August 11 and continuing for some zones through Friday August 13 at 8PM and others Saturday August 14 at 7PM. The Watch was upgraded to a warning during the afternoon of August 10.||Fire weather was also a concern during the event, along with air quality impacts from smoke, however, no major impacts were noted during the period of unusually warm weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A period of much above normal temperatures affected the Seattle area around mid-August. High temperatures ranged from the mid 80s to low 90s during this period, with the temperature peaking August 12-August 13 at 93 degrees, both of which were record high temperatures. Low temperatures during this period ranged from the mid to upper 60s.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Southwest Interior experienced a stretch of heat towards mid August. The ASOS sensor at Olympia showed high temperatures in the low to mid 90s through the duration of the heat event, with a record high temperatures of 96 recorded on August 12. Low temperatures through the event ranged from the mid to upper 50s.||Centralia also recorded temperatures in the low to mid 90s. A high temperature of 95 was recorded on August 12 and August 13. Low temperatures stayed in the mid 60s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure aloft centered over southern Nevada August 3 and 4 provided for a period of excessive heat over the Kern County Deserts prompting an Excessive Heat Warning for both days. In addition, much of the San Joaquin Valley was impacted by significant heat on August 4. Temperatures cooled to below dangerous levels on August 5 as a low pressure system pushed through northern California and weakened the ridge.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 108 and 114 degrees on August 3 and August 4.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Three to four days of oppressive heat created hazardous conditions. From the 10th to the 12th, heat indices peaked at or above 105 degrees each afternoon. The oppressive heat started on the 9th along and west of a line from Mount Vernon to Metropolis. At the Carbondale airport, the highest heat index of this multi-day period was 108 degrees on the 10th. A rather strong southwest wind flow of hot and humid air prevailed between a slow-moving cold front over the Plains and a stationary high pressure center near the Carolina coast.

Unseasonably hot temperatures and high dewpoints occurred across the region in advance of a slow moving cold front. Temperatures ranged from around 90 to the mid 90s...with dewpoints in the lower 70s. Apparent temperatures ranged from the mid 90s to low 100's.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Apparent temperatures ranged through the 90s to around 100.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A stretch of warm weather affected the valleys and lower elevations of the Central Cascades of King and Snohomish Counties. Monroe recorded temperatures in the upper 80s to low 90s during the event, with a record high of 91 on August 13 and August 14. Low temperatures ranged from the mid 50s to around 60.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level ridge of high pressure began to build into the region around August 11, remaining in place through August 13 before pushing eastward. As the upper level ridge influence increased over the region, the lower level flow turned easterly, creating a downsloping effect across much of Western Washington. As a result of this setup, very warm temperatures were forecast for most of the area, with 850mb temperatures expected to peak near 25C during the heart of the event, with surface temperatures ranging from the mid 80s to near 100 and low temperatures during the overnight period ranging from the mid 60s to low 70s.||Excessive Heat Watch was issued on August 8, several days prior to the event, valid for all included zones beginning 12PM on Wednesday August 11 and continuing for some zones through Friday August 13 at 8PM and others Saturday August 14 at 7PM. The Watch was upgraded to a warning during the afternoon of August 10.||Fire weather was also a concern during the event, along with air quality impacts from smoke, however, no major impacts were noted during the period of unusually warm weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A stretch of unusually warm weather affected the valleys and lower elevations of the Cascades of Lewis and Pierce Counties. Temperature recordings at Longmire at Mount Rainier National Park showed temperatures ranging from the mid 80s to upper 90s through the event, with record high temperatures of 98 degrees set on August 13 and August 14. Low temperatures ranged from the mid to upper 50s.||Cedar Lake also recorded temperatures in the mid to upper 80s, with a record high of 87 on August 14.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere developed over the south central United States during late August. Afternoon temperatures reaching the upper 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of northeastern Oklahoma on the 20th.

A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere developed over the south central United States during late August. Afternoon temperatures reaching the upper 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of northeastern Oklahoma on the 20th.

A strong ridge of high pressure aloft centered over southern Nevada August 3 and 4 provided for a period of excessive heat over the Kern County Deserts prompting an Excessive Heat Warning for both days. In addition, much of the San Joaquin Valley was impacted by significant heat on August 4. Temperatures cooled to below dangerous levels on August 5 as a low pressure system pushed through northern California and weakened the ridge.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 104 and 108 degrees on August 4.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Three to four days of oppressive heat created hazardous conditions. From the 10th to the 12th, heat indices peaked at or above 105 degrees each afternoon. The oppressive heat started on the 9th along and west of a line from Mount Vernon to Metropolis. At the Carbondale airport, the highest heat index of this multi-day period was 108 degrees on the 10th. A rather strong southwest wind flow of hot and humid air prevailed between a slow-moving cold front over the Plains and a stationary high pressure center near the Carolina coast.

An upper level ridge of high pressure was centered over the Ark-La-Tex throughout the third and fourth weeks of August, before expanding east into the Mississippi Valley. This resulted in temperatures climbing into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees across portions of extreme Eastern Texas from August 23rd-26th, with little mixing of dew points observed during the period. As a result, heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees each day across portions of extreme East and Deep East Texas, before the ridge aloft weakened by the 27th, with slightly lower temperatures and heat indices observed.

A dome of high pressure settled across eastern New York from Wednesday, August 11 to Friday, August 13 bringing high heat and humidity each day, mainly during the afternoon hours. Heat indices reached 95 to 104 degrees across parts of the area each of these days with areas along the Hudson River from Albany and points southward reaching 105 to 110 on Thursday, August 12. The Hudson Valley Regional Airport recorded an official heat wave with high temperatures all three days in the low to mid-90s.

Unseasonably hot temperatures and high dewpoints occurred across the region in advance of a slow moving cold front. Temperatures ranged from around 90 to the mid 90s...with dewpoints in the lower 70s. Apparent temperatures ranged from the mid 90s to low 100's.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Apparent temperatures ranged through the 90s to around 100.
