EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of high pressure which had been centered over the Great Basin built westward into central California on August 14 and brought dangerous heat to portions of the central California interior between August 14 and August 16. Several stations in the Kern County Deserts had afternoon highs at 110 Degrees F or higher each day between August 14 and August 16. Hot daytime temperatures were also common throughout the San Joaquin Valley and West Side Hills where afternoon highs around 105 Degrees F were common. The high began to weaken on August 17 and daytime temperatures trended lower. By August 18, temperatures across the area were close to their seasonal normals.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 102 and 106 degrees between August 14 and August 16.

An upper level ridge of high pressure was anchored from Nebraska/Kansas southeast across portions of the Lower Mississippi Valley through August 1st, resulting in very hot temperatures across the Ark-La-Tex as readings climbed into the mid and upper 90s. Very little mixing of dew points occurred throughout the day, which when combined with these hot temperatures, resulted in oppressively hot conditions as heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees across much of Southeast Oklahoma. The heat wave finally ended on August 2nd as a weak cool front and scattered showers and thunderstorms moved through the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Some areas reached near 100 degrees on August 2nd with 90s thereafter.

Upper-level high pressure prevailed across the region resulting in high heat and humidity. Heat index values at 105 degrees and greater were widespread across the St. Louis metro area from August 10th through 12th.  Due to 4 days of heat index values at 105 degrees or greater (August 9th through 12th), an Excessive Heat Warning was issued.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values were in excess of 105 degrees for a 4 day stretch across the St. Louis Metro area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of high pressure which had been centered over the Great Basin built westward into central California on August 14 and brought dangerous heat to portions of the central California interior between August 14 and August 16. Several stations in the Kern County Deserts had afternoon highs at 110 Degrees F or higher each day between August 14 and August 16. Hot daytime temperatures were also common throughout the San Joaquin Valley and West Side Hills where afternoon highs around 105 Degrees F were common. The high began to weaken on August 17 and daytime temperatures trended lower. By August 18, temperatures across the area were close to their seasonal normals.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 102 and 106 degrees between August 14 and August 16.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Three days of oppressive heat created hazardous conditions. From the 10th to the 12th, heat indices peaked around 105 degrees each afternoon. At the Evansville airport, the highest heat index of this multi-day period was 105 degrees on the 12th. A rather strong southwest wind flow of hot and humid air prevailed between a slow-moving cold front over the Plains and a stationary high pressure center near the Carolina coast.

Three to four days of oppressive heat created hazardous conditions. From the 9th to the 12th, heat indices peaked at or above 105 degrees each afternoon. The oppressive heat actually started on the 10th in the Henderson/Owensboro area and adjacent counties. At the Paducah airport, the highest heat index of this multi-day period was 105 degrees on the 10th. The highest heat index during this heat wave at Princeton was 108 degrees. A rather strong southwest wind flow of hot and humid air prevailed between a slow-moving cold front over the Plains and a stationary high pressure center near the Carolina coast.

An upper level ridge of high pressure was anchored from Nebraska/Kansas southeast across portions of the Lower Mississippi Valley through August 1st, resulting in very hot temperatures across the Ark-La-Tex as readings climbed into the mid and upper 90s. Very little mixing of dew points occurred throughout the day, which when combined with these hot temperatures, resulted in oppressively hot conditions as heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees across much of Southwest Arkansas. The heat wave finally ended on August 2nd as a weak cool front and scattered showers and thunderstorms moved through the region.

An upper level ridge of high pressure was centered over the Ark-La-Tex throughout the third and fourth weeks of August, before expanding east into the Mississippi Valley. This resulted in temperatures climbing into the mid and upper 90s across the western sections of East Texas on August 25th, with little mixing of dew points observed. As a result, heat indices ranged from 105-108 degrees each day across the western sections of East Texas, before better mixing occurred on the 26th with lower heat indices observed.

A dome of high pressure settled across southern Vermont from Wednesday, August 11 to Friday, August 13 bringing high heat and humidity each day, mainly during the afternoon hours. Heat indices reached 95 to 104 degrees each of these days across Bennington and eastern Windham counties.

A dome of high pressure settled across western Massachusetts from Wednesday, August 11 to Friday, August 13 bringing high heat and humidity each day, mainly during the afternoon hours. Heat indices reached 95 to 102 degrees each of these days.

An upper level high pressure system over the Desert Southwest led to hot temperatures across Southern California from August 1st through 5th, along with areas of dense fog near the coast on August 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures over 115 degrees occurred. Borrego Springs reached 119 degrees on the 4th of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level high pressure system over the Desert Southwest led to hot temperatures across Southern California from August 1st through 5th, along with areas of dense fog near the coast on August 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures between 95 and 105 degrees occurred. Ranchita RAWS hit 105 degrees on the 4th of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level high pressure system over the Desert Southwest led to hot temperatures across Southern California from August 1st through 5th, along with areas of dense fog near the coast on August 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures between 95 and 100 degrees occurred. Santee reported a high of 100 degrees on the 2nd of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat Index values across roughly the eastern half of the region reached 105-110 degrees in the afternoon hours of the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat Index values reached 105-110 degrees in the afternoon hours of the 1st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere developed over the south central United States during late August. Afternoon temperatures reaching the upper 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of northeastern Oklahoma on the 22nd.

Upper-level high pressure prevailed across the region resulting in high heat and humidity. Heat index values at 105 degrees and greater were widespread across the St. Louis metro area from August 10th through 12th.  Due to 4 days of heat index values at 105 degrees or greater (August 9th through 12th), an Excessive Heat Warning was issued.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values were in excess of 105 degrees for a 4 day stretch across the St. Louis Metro area. Nine heat related illnesses were reported in St. Louis County.

An area of high pressure over the Southwest led to warm conditions over SoCal, especially across the deserts on August 15th and 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Areas of the High Desert reported temperatures between 100 and 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged heat event occurred from Labor Day Weekend through the following weekend across Southern California from September 4th through September 13th. The first peak of the heat occurred on Sunday, September 5th; this was the hottest stretch for some mountain locations, the High Desert and the Inland Empire. A second peak occurred on Monday, September 13, when some of the highest temperatures occurred across some mountain locations and the lower deserts. At six locations, the highest temperatures of the event occurred on September 13, when all heat products had expired.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The High Desert saw excessive heat the first full week of September, with heat peaking on Wednesday, September 8th, when highs reached the upper-100s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged heat event occurred from Labor Day Weekend through the following weekend across Southern California from September 4th through September 13th. The first peak of the heat occurred on Sunday, September 5th; this was the hottest stretch for some mountain locations, the High Desert and the Inland Empire. A second peak occurred on Monday, September 13, when some of the highest temperatures occurred across some mountain locations and the lower deserts. At six locations, the highest temperatures of the event occurred on September 13, when all heat products had expired.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Much of the Coachella Valley saw excessive heat Labor Day Weekend through the following weekend. The first peak occurred on Sunday, September 5th, when highs ranged from the upper-100s to the mid-110s. The heat persisted through the following weekend, when the highest temperatures of event occurred. Several locations saw their highest temperatures of the heat event on Monday, September 13, after all heat products had expired, including Ocotillo Wells (116/91), Thermal (111) and Indio (112/87).||Several sites saw very warm overnight low temperatures, exacerbating the heat risk through the event. Indio set a record for the highest minimum temperature on September 13, with the overnight low falling to 87, breaking the previous record of 86 set in 2015.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions persisted for the first few days of the month, with heat indcies over 105 reported in portions of central and eastern Oklahoma.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several heat related illnesses were reported across the OKC metro over this three day period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge anchored over West Texas into Western Oklahoma and Western Kansas expanded farther east into the Central and Southern Plains on September 1st, resulting in a return of very hot temperatures as readings rose back into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees across all of the Four State Region. A southerly low level flow maintained the very humid conditions in place, with little mixing of dewpoints observed, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees across McCurtain County Oklahoma. Slightly cooler temperatures were observed on the 2nd as a weak surface trough drifted southwest into the area from Southwest Arkansas, which resulted in scattered showers and thunderstorms farther south over Northeast Texas.

An upper level ridge anchored over West Texas into Western Oklahoma and Western Kansas expanded farther east into the Central and Southern Plains on September 1st, resulting in a return of very hot temperatures as readings rose back into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees across all of the Four State Region. A southerly low level flow maintained the very humid conditions in place, with little mixing of dewpoints observed, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees across Southwest Arkansas. Scattered showers and thunderstorms did develop during the afternoon across portions of Southwest Arkansas, bringing some relief to the heat. Slightly cooler temperatures were observed on the 2nd as a weak surface trough drifted southwest through the area, which resulted in scattered showers and thunderstorms farther south over Northeast Texas and Northwest Louisiana.

High pressure over California resulted in very hot daytime temperatures and warm overnight low temperatures across interior Northern California. High to very high heat risk impacted the region. One daily high temperature record was broken. During the event, cooling centers were made available to the public across interior Northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Central Sacramento Valley region saw high temperatures reach upwards of 105 degrees during the event. On September 7th, Marysville recorded a high temperature of 106 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over California resulted in very hot daytime temperatures and warm overnight low temperatures across interior Northern California. High to very high heat risk impacted the region. One daily high temperature record was broken. During the event, cooling centers were made available to the public across interior Northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sacramento region saw high temperatures reach in excess of 105 degrees. On the 8th, downtown Sacramento reached 106 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over California resulted in very hot daytime temperatures and warm overnight low temperatures across interior Northern California. High to very high heat risk impacted the region. One daily high temperature record was broken. During the event, cooling centers were made available to the public across interior Northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Delta regions saw high temperatures reach upwards of 105 degrees. Nut tree airport in Vacaville reported a high temperature of 108 degrees on the 8th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over California resulted in very hot daytime temperatures and warm overnight low temperatures across interior Northern California. High to very high heat risk impacted the region. One daily high temperature record was broken. During the event, cooling centers were made available to the public across interior Northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Northern San Joaquin Valley saw high temperatures reach over 100 degrees during the event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures around 105 degrees were experienced across the Tohono O'odham Nation on September 7. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two males found in the desert.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 3 to 5 degrees above normal, around 105 degrees, were experienced across the Tohono O'odham Nation causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached on September 7. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two males found in the desert, one on the far western edge of the Tohono O'odham Nation near Sweetwater, and another northeast of Sells.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced west and south of Tucson September 11 through 14. The hottest two days were the 12th and 13th when high temperatures fell just shy of records across much of Pima County and topped out between 104 and 109 degrees. During the four day period, the Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for seven individuals found in the desert, one at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, five on the Tohono O'odham Nation, and one in Santa Cruz County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 3 to 5 degrees above normal, around 105 degrees, were experienced across the Tohono O'odham Nation causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached on September 11. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one female found in the desert west of Vamori.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface area of high pressure settled over the Great Basin, producing Santa Ana winds and a shallow marine layer with warm weather. This lead to gusty winds in the mountains and foothills with areas of fog near the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Warm temperatures occurred with many highs in the mid 90s, including the Chino ASOS hitting 97 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface area of high pressure settled over the Great Basin, producing Santa Ana winds and a shallow marine layer with warm weather. This lead to gusty winds in the mountains and foothills with areas of fog near the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Warm temperatures occurred with many highs in the low 90s, including Fullerton ASOS, which hit 93 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over the Desert Southwest brought four days of excessive heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached three days in a row.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged heat event occurred from Labor Day Weekend through the following weekend across Southern California from September 4th through September 13th. The first peak of the heat occurred on Sunday, September 5th; this was the hottest stretch for some mountain locations, the High Desert and the Inland Empire. A second peak occurred on Monday, September 13, when some of the highest temperatures occurred across some mountain locations and the lower deserts. At six locations, the highest temperatures of the event occurred on September 13, when all heat products had expired.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures across the San Diego County Mountains and valleys consistently reaching the mid-90s from Saturday, September 4th through September 13th. Eight Preliminary Prehospital Heat Related Calls occurred from September 5 through September 10, seven of which were mild cases, and one that was a moderate case of heat-related illness.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures reached the lower-100s on Saturday, September 4th. The heat peaked across the Inland Empire on Sunday, September 5th, when highs reached 108 degrees in Ontario, and 107 degrees in Riverside. The heat ramped back up the following weekend, with high temperatures reaching the low-100s September 11th through September 13th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 600dm ridge of high pressure centered over the Desert Southwest in mid-June retrograded over to the West Coast/East-Central Pacific Ocean by the start of the 3rd week of June. The pattern began to amplify on June 20th, with the ridge axis building along the West Coast, coinciding with a large area of low pressure deepening over Hudson Bay to the east. This feature, along with deepening low pressure over the Gulf of Alaska were the primary factors in the omega block setting up off the Pacific Northwest Coast by the end of the week. The strength of the Hudson Bay vortex kept the 600dm ridge high centered over the Pacific Northwest for nearly a week, yielding record breaking temperatures (multiple days of over 100 degree temperatures in a row with low temperatures resembling the average high temperatures for the time of year).||The record-breaking heat from this anomalous pattern led to multiple heat-related fatalities (heat stroke and heat stress) across Western Washington is also expected to be related to numerous drownings across the area, largely in part due to hypothermia as people sought reprieve from the heat in local area lakes and large bodies of water. In addition, several brush fires were also ignited due to dry fuels present amidst hot temperatures. All fires were contained without major impacts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A section of pavement came loose/buckled on NB I-405 and I-5 in Tukwila, causing road and highway closures for several hours during the evening commute.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong dome of hot high pressure over the Inland Northwest pushed afternoon high temperatures into record territory. In late June 2021, a long-lived heatwave broke many daily, monthly, and all time maximum high and low temperature records at several stations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperature observations taken at Lewiston Airport were unseasonably warm from June 26th through July 2nd. No records were broken in the Lewiston Area; however, high temperatures ranged from 103 to 115 degrees with lows only cooling to 67 to 78 degrees. On the 29th, Avista Utilities performed blackouts in Lewiston to help cope with the exceptionally hot temperatures. There are no known heat-related deaths.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong dome of hot high pressure over the Inland Northwest pushed afternoon high temperatures into record territory. In late June 2021, a long-lived heatwave broke many daily, monthly, and all time maximum high and low temperature records at several stations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The excessive heat on June 26 through 30th brought record breaking high temperatures across the Idaho Palouse. Three towns have new June high temperatures when afternoon highs reached Moscow at 105 degrees, Plummer at 107 degrees, and Potlatch at 107 degrees. There are no known heat-related deaths.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong dome of hot high pressure over the Inland Northwest pushed afternoon high temperatures into record territory. In late June 2021, a long-lived heatwave broke many daily, monthly, and all time maximum high and low temperature records at several stations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the late June heatwave, the Coeur d'Alene Airport had four consecutive days with afternoon highs at 100 degrees or above. Two of those days were 108 degrees. On June 28th through 30th, Post Falls high temperatures were 105 to 108 degrees. The Coeur d'Alene Ironman was held on the 27th and extra precautions were taken to prevent heat exhaustion due to the extreme temperatures. There is no known count of heat-related injuries at the event.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: State route 544 milepost 7 near Everson was closed as asphalt roadway buckled and was deemed unsafe for travel. Detours were put in place with highway repair complete the morning following the incident.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Concrete panels along NB I-5 to I-705 experienced period damage and needed continuous repairs from Jun 27-Jun 29. This caused 3 lanes of the collector-distributor to close, causing traffic backups and detours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong dome of hot high pressure over the Inland Northwest pushed afternoon high temperatures into record territory. In late June 2021, a long-lived heatwave broke many daily, monthly, and all time maximum high and low temperature records at several stations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An extended period of excessive heat occurred across the Wenatchee area from June 26th to July 2nd. Afternoon high temperatures ranged from 102 to 114 degrees most afternoons. Overnight lows only fell into the mid-to-upper 70 degrees. There were two all time records set in the Wenatchee area. On the 28th, a new record high maximum temperature was set at Chelan with a high of 111 degrees. On the 30th, Wenatchee's overnight low only dropped to 79 degrees setting a new record high minimum temperature. Numerous cooling centers opened for those without air conditioning during the extreme heat. There are no known heat related deaths.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong dome of hot high pressure over the Inland Northwest pushed afternoon high temperatures into record territory. In late June 2021, a long-lived heatwave broke many daily, monthly, and all time maximum high and low temperature records at several stations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two new all time records were set across the Palouse. The town of Rosalia set a new all-time maximum temperature of 111 degrees on June 28th and Pullman reached 106 degrees on June 29th. There was a report, from the Washington State Department of Transportation, that there was pavement buckling on Highway 195 due to the heat. Due to the extreme high temperatures, Pullman cooling center was established for those without air conditioning across the area. There are no known heat related deaths.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: From June 26 to 30th, Moses Lake and Ephrata had high temperatures reach between 103 to 116 degrees, which is abnormally warm for end of June. Ephrata broke their all time high maximum temperature when the airport reached 116 degrees on June 29th. Local libraries were arranged to act as cooling centers for residents without air conditioning. There are no know heat-related deaths.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Record breaking heat across the Seattle metro area led to multiple heat related fatalities, numerous pavement buckles requiring road closures and repair, the closing of University bridge for marine traffic due to excessive heat, lowering of speed limits to Sound Transit, millions of gallons of water used, the highest energy usage in Seattle public utilities history during the summer months, the closing of the Seattle monorail, and the death of dozens of Caspian Terns.||Temperatures began to rise in the Seattle metro on 6/26 to 102 degrees, followed by an increase in several degrees to 104 on 6/27, with a peak and all time record high temperature on 6/28  of 108. Temperatures slowly began to cool as the month concluded.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Record breaking heat affected the Tacoma area for several days, beginning on 6/26 and peaking 6/27-6/28.  A high temperature of 99 was recorded on 6/27, with an (unofficial) all time record high temperature of 105 of 6/27. Temperatures then reached 99 and 97 on the afternoon of 6/28 and 6/29, respectively before a gradual cool down began at the conclusion of the month. Several reports of road buckling/road damage around Tacoma.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long lasting heat wave occurred across Southern California from June 14th through the 20th, where many daily records were broken. A wildfire also broke out in the Riverside County Mountains on the 13th, which led to damages and road closures. Isolated thunderstorms also produced gusty winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extreme heat occurred across this region with temperatures peaking on June 16th, where Apple Valley hit 112 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long lasting heat wave occurred across Southern California from June 14th through the 20th, where many daily records were broken. A wildfire also broke out in the Riverside County Mountains on the 13th, which led to damages and road closures. Isolated thunderstorms also produced gusty winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extreme heat occurred across the Coachella Valley with temperatures over 120 degrees. Thermal reported a high of 119 twice along with a morning low temperature of 90. Palm Springs tied their all-time record high temperature of 123 degrees on June 17th and reported a low temperature of 90 the following morning. There was one heat-related fatality on June 19th in Palm Springs, where a man simply collapsed while walking down the city streets.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long lasting heat wave occurred across Southern California from June 14th through the 20th, where many daily records were broken. A wildfire also broke out in the Riverside County Mountains on the 13th, which led to damages and road closures. Isolated thunderstorms also produced gusty winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Scorching heat occurred across this region with temperatures over 120 degrees. Ocotillo Wells reported a high 123 degrees twice on June 17th and 18th, as well as a low temperature of 98 degrees on the morning of June 20th. Two hikers had to be rescued from the Borrego Palm Canyon Trail around 12:40 PM on the 19th due to heat related illness. One hiker died at the scene, and the other was transported to a hospital and is in critical condition. A firefighter who was aiding with the rescue also suffered from heat illness, though his condition is unknown. It was around 112 degrees at the time.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Record breaking heat from 6/26-6/29. High temperatures at the Bremerton airport reached 90 degrees on 6/26, followed by a noticeable warmup on 6/27 at 100 degrees. An (unofficial) all time record high temperature was reported on 6/28 at 102 degrees. The heat stuck around for one more day on 6/29 where high temperatures reached 101 in the afternoon before a gradual cool down commenced at the conclusion of the month.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures occurred across the area with Idyllwild peaking at 104 degrees on June 16th. A female hiker died on the Pacific Crest Trail near Anza from heat stroke and another hiker was helicopter air lifted to hospital.

Temperatures then cooled down back into the low 80s at the conclusion of the month, ending the record breaking heat.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An extended period of hot temperatures affected western Whatcom County at the end of June. High temperatures reached the mid 90s on the afternoons of 6/26 and 6/27 according to the Bellingham Airport ASOS. Temperatures then peaked on 6/28 with a high temperature of 99 at the Bellingham Airport. This then became an all time record high temperature. By 6/29, temperatures cooled back into the upper 70s, ending the extended period of record breaking hot weather. In addition to the heat, there were some reports of road buckling on SR 544 near MP 7 near Everson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level high pressure system brought low dewpoints and unusually hot temperatures to the higher elevations of the Davis and Guadalupe Mountains, as well as along the Rio Grande.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A high of 104 degrees was measured at Guadalupe Peak.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level high pressure system brought low dewpoints and unusually hot temperatures to the higher elevations of the Davis and Guadalupe Mountains, as well as along the Rio Grande.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A high of 102 degrees was measured at Fort Davis.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level high pressure system brought low dewpoints and unusually hot temperatures to the higher elevations of the Davis and Guadalupe Mountains, as well as along the Rio Grande.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A high of 116 degrees was measured at Rio Grande Village.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough caused westerly winds across the Mountains of West Texas and southeastern New Mexico. Very low dewpoints helped temperatures to soar well above normal causing excessive heat conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A high of around 100 degrees was estimated in the Chinati Mountains.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough caused westerly winds across the Mountains of West Texas and southeastern New Mexico. Very low dewpoints helped temperatures to soar well above normal causing excessive heat conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A high of 102 degrees was recorded at Guadalupe Peak.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 600dm ridge of high pressure centered over the Desert Southwest in mid-June retrograded over to the West Coast/East-Central Pacific Ocean by the start of the 3rd week of June. The pattern began to amplify on June 20th, with the ridge axis building along the West Coast, coinciding with a large area of low pressure deepening over Hudson Bay to the east. This feature, along with deepening low pressure over the Gulf of Alaska were the primary factors in the omega block setting up off the Pacific Northwest Coast by the end of the week. The strength of the Hudson Bay vortex kept the 600dm ridge high centered over the Pacific Northwest for nearly a week, yielding record breaking temperatures (multiple days of over 100 degree temperatures in a row with low temperatures resembling the average high temperatures for the time of year).||The record-breaking heat from this anomalous pattern led to multiple heat-related fatalities (heat stroke and heat stress) across Western Washington is also expected to be related to numerous drownings across the area, largely in part due to hypothermia as people sought reprieve from the heat in local area lakes and large bodies of water. In addition, several brush fires were also ignited due to dry fuels present amidst hot temperatures. All fires were contained without major impacts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Record breaking heat affected the North Coast of Washington at the end of June as a strong area of high pressure built into the region. The hottest afternoon temperatures were reported on the afternoon of 6/28, with the Quillayute Airport reporting an all time record high temperature of 110 degrees. The following day, onshore flow led to rapid cooling back into the upper 60s.

The pattern began to amplify on June 20th, with the ridge axis building along the West Coast, coinciding with a large area of low pressure deepening over Hudson Bay to the east. The strength of the Hudson Bay vortex kept the 600dm ridge high centered over the Pacific Northwest for nearly a week, yielding record breaking temperatures (multiple days of over 100 degree temperatures in a row with low temperatures resembling the average high temperatures for the time of year).||The record-breaking heat from this anomalous pattern led to multiple heat-related fatalities (heat stroke and heat stress) across Western Washington is also expected to be related to numerous drownings across the area, largely in part due to hypothermia as people sought reprieve from the heat in local area lakes and large bodies of water. In addition, several brush fires were also ignited due to dry fuels present amidst hot temperatures. All fires were contained without major impacts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An extended period of hot weather affected the San Juan Islands at the end of June. The ASOS at Friday Harbor recorded high temperatures in the mid 90s from 6/26-6/28 before temperatures finally began to cool on 6/29.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures and humidity combined to lead to a period of oppressive heat on the 9th through the 13th, with heat advisories issued for much of central and western Oklahoma.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: More than 75 heat-related emergency calls were received in the OKC area during this stretch of hot weather.

The pattern began to amplify on June 20th, with the ridge axis building along the West Coast, coinciding with a large area of low pressure deepening over Hudson Bay to the east. This feature, along with deepening low pressure over the Gulf of Alaska were the primary factors in the omega block setting up off the Pacific Northwest Coast by the end of the week. The strength of the Hudson Bay vortex kept the 600dm ridge high centered over the Pacific Northwest for nearly a week, yielding record breaking temperatures (multiple days of over 100 degree temperatures in a row with low temperatures resembling the average high temperatures for the time of year).||The record-breaking heat from this anomalous pattern led to multiple heat-related fatalities (heat stroke and heat stress) across Western Washington is also expected to be related to numerous drownings across the area, largely in part due to hypothermia as people sought reprieve from the heat in local area lakes and large bodies of water. In addition, several brush fires were also ignited due to dry fuels present amidst hot temperatures. All fires were contained without major impacts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An extended period of hot temperatures affected Western Skagit county at the end of June. The official COOP site was not active during the heat wave, but observations at KAWO reported a high temperature of 103 on 6/28. Temperatures peaked on 6/28, with hot conditions present from 6/26-6/27. Temperatures began to cool on 6/29 through the rest of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure built across the Rio Grande Valley/Deep South Texas region during the June 6-8 period and onshore winds remained persistent. Dewpoints in the mid 70s lead to very humid conditions across the area, and combined with highest ambient temperatures across portions of Zapata and Starr counties in the triple digits, heat indices met or exceeded 111 or 112 degrees. Heat Advisories were in effect each afternoon June 6th through 8th for heat indices of 111 degrees or greater for a few hours across Zapata, Starr and Jim Hogg County on June 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Zapata County Airport Automated Weather Observing System reported a little over 2 hours of heat indices meeting or exceeding 111 degrees. There were no illnesses or fatalities reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure built across the Rio Grande Valley/Deep South Texas region during the June 6-8 period and onshore winds remained persistent. Dewpoints in the mid 70s lead to very humid conditions across the area, and combined with highest ambient temperatures across portions of Zapata and Starr counties in the triple digits, heat indices met or exceeded 111 or 112 degrees. Heat Advisories were in effect each afternoon June 6th through 8th for heat indices of 111 degrees or greater for a few hours across Zapata, Starr and Jim Hogg County on June 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Zapata County Automated Weather Observing System reported just over 2 hours of heat indices meeting or exceeding 111 degrees, and by proxy, it is reasonable that Starr County near the Rio Grande also received 2 hours of these conditions. The Mesowest locations near Falcon Dam reported several hours between 111 and 116, but these raw data are considered several degrees too high (in both temperature and dew point). A reduction supports two to three hours of 111. There were no illnesses or fatalities reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 600dm ridge of high pressure centered over the Desert Southwest in mid-June retrograded over to the West Coast/East-Central Pacific Ocean by the start of the 3rd week of June. The pattern began to amplify on June 20th, with the ridge axis building along the West Coast, coinciding with a large area of low pressure deepening over Hudson Bay to the east. This feature, along with deepening low pressure over the Gulf of Alaska were the primary factors in the omega block setting up off the Pacific Northwest Coast by the end of the week. The strength of the Hudson Bay vortex kept the 600dm ridge high centered over the Pacific Northwest for nearly a week, yielding record breaking temperatures (multiple days of over 100 degree temperatures in a row with low temperatures resembling the average high temperatures for the time of year).||The record-breaking heat from this anomalous pattern led to multiple heat-related fatalities (heat stroke and heat stress) across Western Washington is also expected to be related to numerous drownings across the area, largely in part due to hypothermia as people sought reprieve from the heat in local area lakes and large bodies of water. In addition, several brush fires were also ignited due to dry fuels present amidst hot temperatures. All fires were contained without major impacts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Record breaking heat led to multiple days of high temperatures above 100 degrees. On 6/26 high temperatures rose to 102 degrees, with 6/27 several degrees warmer at 105. On 6/28 an all time record high temperature was set at the Olympia Airport of 110 degrees. Temperatures then began to cool during the final two days of June.||Centralia also unofficially tied its all time record high temperature of 107 degrees on 6/28.

The pattern began to amplify on June 20th, with the ridge axis building along the West Coast, coinciding with a large area of low pressure deepening over Hudson Bay to the east. This feature, along with deepening low pressure over the Gulf of Alaska were the primary factors in the omega block setting up off the Pacific Northwest Coast by the end of the week. The strength of the Hudson Bay vortex kept the 600dm ridge high centered over the Pacific Northwest for nearly a week, yielding record breaking temperatures (multiple days of over 100 degree temperatures in a row with low temperatures resembling the average high temperatures for the time of year).||The record-breaking heat from this anomalous pattern led to multiple heat-related fatalities (heat stroke and heat stress) across Western Washington is also expected to be related to numerous drownings across the area, largely in part due to hypothermia as people sought reprieve from the heat in local area lakes and large bodies of water. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Recorded breaking heat affected the central Coast of Washington at the end of June as a strong area of high pressure became centered over the region. Temperatures began to increase into the upper 80s on 6/26, with temperatures peaking on 6/27 and remaining hot through 6/28. The Hoquiam airport recorded an all time record high temperature  on 6/27 of 103 degrees. At the conclusion of the month, temperatures began to cool back into the upper 60s as onshore flow strengthened and high pressure weakened.||Aberdeen also recorded an unofficial all time record high temperature on 6/28 of 108 degrees.

CZ_NAME: CASCADES OF PIERCE AND LEWIS COUNTIES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 600dm ridge of high pressure centered over the Desert Southwest in mid-June retrograded over to the West Coast/East-Central Pacific Ocean by the start of the 3rd week of June. The pattern began to amplify on June 20th, with the ridge axis building along the West Coast, coinciding with a large area of low pressure deepening over Hudson Bay to the east. This feature, along with deepening low pressure over the Gulf of Alaska were the primary factors in the omega block setting up off the Pacific Northwest Coast by the end of the week. The strength of the Hudson Bay vortex kept the 600dm ridge high centered over the Pacific Northwest for nearly a week, yielding record breaking temperatures (multiple days of over 100 degree temperatures in a row with low temperatures resembling the average high temperatures for the time of year).||The record-breaking heat from this anomalous pattern led to multiple heat-related fatalities (heat stroke and heat stress) across Western Washington is also expected to be related to numerous drownings across the area, largely in part due to hypothermia as people sought reprieve from the heat in local area lakes and large bodies of water. In addition, several brush fires were also ignited due to dry fuels present amidst hot temperatures. All fires were contained without major impacts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An extended period of heat affected the Cascades of Pierce and Lewis Counties at the end of June. Temperatures began to climb  into the upper 70s and lower 80s at Paradise on 6/26 and continued through 6/28. On 6/29, the Paradise Ranger Station recorded an unofficial all time record high temperature of 90. Temperatures then remained above normal through the end of the month but were not as hot as the previous several days.||Longmire also unofficially tied its all time record high temperature on both 6/29 and 6/30 at 105 degrees.||Due to the extended period of extreme heat, flooding from glacial/snow melt washed out the Nisqually bridge near Cougar Rock. This affected hiking near Mount Rainier National Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid level ridge of high pressure allowed for effective heating across the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas  on June 21st. These hot temperatures combined with elevated dew points and relative humidity values lead to heat indices exceeding 115 degrees for just over 2 hours across portions of the western counties of the Lower Valley. Other areas reported heat indices of 111 degrees or greater for a couple of hours in the afternoon as well. An Excessive Heat Warning was in effect for Zapata, Starr, and Southern Hidalgo County and a Heat Advisory was in effect for Northern Hidalgo and Jim Hogg County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Weather Observing System at the Zapata County Airport reported 3 hours of heat indices exceeding 115 degrees starting at 3 PM CDT, and by proxy, it's safe to assume that Starr County received similar conditions for this time period. The Mesowest location at Falcon Lake reported excessive heat values of 119 to 123, but these are considered several degrees too high based on comparative observations in past events. ||There were no known heat related casualties in these areas as of this writing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid level ridge of high pressure allowed for effective heating across the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas  on June 21st. These hot temperatures combined with elevated dew points and relative humidity values lead to heat indices exceeding 115 degrees for just over 2 hours across portions of the western counties of the Lower Valley. Other areas reported heat indices of 111 degrees or greater for a couple of hours in the afternoon as well. An Excessive Heat Warning was in effect for Zapata, Starr, and Southern Hidalgo County and a Heat Advisory was in effect for Northern Hidalgo and Jim Hogg County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Weather Observing System at Zapata County Airport, 4 miles northeast of the city, reported 3 hours of heat indices exceeding 115 degrees starting at 3 PM CDT. There were no known heat related illnesses or casualties as of this writing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid level ridge of high pressure allowed for effective heating across the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas  on June 21st. These hot temperatures combined with elevated dew points and relative humidity values lead to heat indices exceeding 115 degrees for just over 2 hours across portions of the western counties of the Lower Valley. Other areas reported heat indices of 111 degrees or greater for a couple of hours in the afternoon as well. An Excessive Heat Warning was in effect for Zapata, Starr, and Southern Hidalgo County and a Heat Advisory was in effect for Northern Hidalgo and Jim Hogg County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Weather Observing System at the South Texas International Airport 11 miles north of Edinburg, along FM 490, reported 3 hours of heat indices reaching or exceeding 111 degrees beginning at 3 PM CDT. There was about a 30 minute period of heat indices exceeding 115 degrees beginning around 3:30 PM, but it was not long enough to meet Excessive Heat Criteria.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first heat wave of the season pushed temperatures well over 100 degrees in much of the Mojave Desert.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached four days in a row.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first heat wave of the season pushed temperatures well over 100 degrees in much of the Mojave Desert.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached three days in a row.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid level ridge of high pressure allowed for effective heating across the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas  on June 21st. These hot temperatures combined with elevated dew points and relative humidity values lead to heat indices exceeding 115 degrees for just over 2 hours across portions of the western counties of the Lower Valley. Other areas reported heat indices of 111 degrees or greater for a couple of hours in the afternoon as well. An Excessive Heat Warning was in effect for Zapata, Starr, and Southern Hidalgo County and a Heat Advisory was in effect for Northern Hidalgo and Jim Hogg County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Weather Observing System at the South Texas International Airport 11 miles north of Edinburg, along FM 490, reported 3 hours of heat indices reaching or exceeding 111 degrees beginning at 3 PM CDT. There was about a 30 minute period of heat indices exceeding 115 degrees beginning around 3:30 PM, but it was not long enough to meet Excessive Heat Criteria.  The sensor location straddles the NWS forecast zones of northern and southern Hidalgo County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures around 100 degrees were experienced on June 2 on the Tohono O'odham Nation. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two males found in the desert.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures 5 to 10 degrees above normal, around 100, occurred on the Tohono O'odham Nation causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached on June 2. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two males found in the desert.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper high pressure center strengthened over the Great Basin during the Labor Day weekend (September 4 to September 6) resulting in temperatures rising to much above normal levels over the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and Kern County Deserts on September 6.  The dangerous heat remained prevalent over the area through September 9 prompting the issuance of heat highlights as the large upper high prodcued a pronounced southeast flow over the area.  A trough moved into northern California during the morning of September 10 bringing an end to the dangerous heat as afternoon highs remained below the century mark at most stations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 105 and 110 degrees on September 9.

The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three males found in the desert, one on the Tohono O'odham Nation and 2 in southeast Pima County.

The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three males found in the desert, one on the Tohono O'odham Nation near Vamori, one near Arivaca, and another north of Amado.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures, 5 to 10 degrees above normal, were experienced on June 6-7 with high temperatures in the upper 90s to 100 degrees, causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three males found in the desert, one on the Tohono O'odham Nation near Vamori, one near Arivaca, and another north of Amado.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures in the upper 90s to 100 degrees were experienced on June 6-7 in the lower elevations of southern Pima County. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three males found in the desert, one on the Tohono O'odham Nation and 2 in southeast Pima County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures, 5 to 10 degrees above normal, were experienced on June 6-7 with high temperatures in the upper 90s to 100 degrees, causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three males found in the desert, one on the Tohono O'odham Nation near Vamori, one near Arivaca, and another north of Amado.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The strong monsoon high centered over the Four Corners led to temperatures approaching 110 degrees at times in Phoenix. Temperatures most nights were 3-4 degrees above normal as lows remained in the upper 80s. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 30 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three fatalities (2 direct and 1 indirect) were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad upper level ridge over the Desert Southwest led to continued above normal temperatures along with excessive heat conditions for the middle part of September. Temperatures most afternoons during this time in Phoenix topped out around 108-109 degrees. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 10 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time. One of these fatalities included a person who died while hiking in Scottsdale. According to local media reports, a couple from Rhode Island started hiking around noon on the 12th at Brown's Ranch Trailhead in Scottsdale. After splitting up during the hike, the wife never returned to their meeting location. Local authorities responded and discovered that the wife had succumbed to the heat.

Upper level ridging over much of the western United States led to deadly heat at the beginning of July. Temperatures at Phoenix Sky Harbor during this time peaked at 107 degrees, which is normal for this time of year. However, low temperatures only cooled to around 90 degrees at times, providing little overnight relief. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 14 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three fatalities (1 direct and 2 indirect) were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

Strong high pressure centered over the Great Basin resulted in temperatures climbing above normal during the first part of September. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 15 heat-associated deaths occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One indirect fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An amplified upper level ridge over the West Coast led to excessive heat conditions across southeast California in late June.
An amplified upper level ridge over the West Coast led to excessive heat conditions across southeast California in late June.

A strong upper level ridge strengthened over the Desert Southwest during the middle part of June with the center of high pressure becoming focused over the Four Corners region. As a result, temperatures warmed up well above normal reaching excessive heat conditions. High temperatures climbed at or above 115 degrees each day (6 days) between the 15th-20th, breaking Phoenix's record for consecutive days of 115+ degree temperatures. Temperatures in Phoenix peaked on the 17th at 118 degrees, breaking the record for the date and becoming the hottest temperature for the whole year. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, sixty heat-associated fatalities occurred as a result of this heat wave.

Strong high pressure encompassing the Desert Southwest led to above normal temperatures, with excessive heat conditions occurring across the Phoenix area between the 9th and 11th. At Phoenix Sky Harbor, temperatures climbed above 110 degrees for six consecutive days between the 6th and 11th, with the warmest highs peaking at 112 degrees. Overnight low temperatures offered little relief from the heat as temperatures only fell to around 90 degrees most nights. On the 9th, Phoenix recorded a low temperature of 93 degrees, setting a new record warm low for the date. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 49 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One direct fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

At Phoenix Sky Harbor, temperatures climbed above 110 degrees for six consecutive days between the 6th and 11th, with the warmest highs peaking at 112 degrees. Overnight low temperatures offered little relief from the heat as temperatures only fell to around 90 degrees most nights. On the 9th, Phoenix recorded a low temperature of 93 degrees, setting a new record warm low for the date. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 49 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.

A strong upper level ridge strengthened over the Desert Southwest during the middle part of June with the center of high pressure becoming focused over the Four Corners region. As a result, temperatures warmed up well above normal reaching excessive heat conditions. High temperatures climbed at or above 115 degrees each day (6 days) between the 15th-20th, breaking Phoenix's record for consecutive days of 115+ degree temperatures. Temperatures in Phoenix peaked on the 17th at 118 degrees, breaking the record for the date and becoming the hottest temperature for the whole year. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, sixty heat-associated fatalities occurred as a result of this heat wave.

A broad upper level ridge over the Desert Southwest led to continued above normal temperatures along with excessive heat conditions for the middle part of September. Temperatures most afternoons during this time in Phoenix topped out around 108-109 degrees. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 10 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time. One of these fatalities included a person who died while hiking in Scottsdale. According to local media reports, a couple from Rhode Island started hiking around noon on the 12th at Brown's Ranch Trailhead in Scottsdale. After splitting up during the hike, the wife never returned to their meeting location. Local authorities responded and discovered that the wife had succumbed to the heat.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge situated over much of the western United States at the end of July led to heat that resulted in several fatalities. One of these fatalities included a woman visiting from Boston who died after becoming overheated while hiking on Camelback Mountain. EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 31-year-old woman visiting from Boston went hiking with a man on Echo Canyon Trail on Camelback Mountain around 1PM MST. The woman became overheated about halfway up the trail and decided to turn around and go back down, while the man continued up the trail. The woman was later discovered and pronounced dead near a home next to the mountain after she was believed to be seeking help. The man and woman were reportedly hiking without any water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper level ridging over much of the western United States led to deadly heat at the beginning of July. Temperatures at Phoenix Sky Harbor during this time peaked at 107 degrees, which is normal for this time of year. However, low temperatures only cooled to around 90 degrees at times, providing little overnight relief. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 14 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two fatalities (1 direct and 1 indirect) were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

Very hot temperatures were experienced in the lower elevations of southeast Arizona August 25 through 27, with high temperatures equaling or exceeding established records in a few locations, and approaching record levels in most others. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one male found in the desert.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot high temperatures of 104 to 114 degrees, or 5 to 11 degrees above normal, occurred in the lower elevations of Pima, southeast Pinal, and northwest sections of Cochise and Graham counties August 25-27 and caused the High Heat Risk category to be reached. The highest temperatures at select locations during the period were 114 degrees (tied record on 8/27) at Ajo, 112 (both records on 8/26 and 8/27) at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, 111 (record on 8/26) at Sells, 108 (one degree shy of the record on 8/27) at Picacho, 106 on 8/26 at Tucson International Airport, 105 on 8/25 and 8/26 at San Carlos and 103 on 8/25 at Cascabel.

Hot temperatures around 105 degrees on the Tohono O'odham Nation and 110 in western Pima County were experienced on July 6.  The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for four males found in the desert.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures 5 degrees above normal near 110 degrees, occurred in western Pima County causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached on July 6. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one male found in the desert west of Ajo.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced in much of southeast Arizona on August 3 and 4 with high temperatures equaling or exceeding established records in a few locations, and approaching record levels in most others. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two males found in the desert in Pima County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot high temperatures of 104 to 115 degrees, or 8 to 12 degrees above normal, occurred in the lower deserts of Pima and Pinal counties August 3-4, and caused the High Heat Risk category to be reached. High temperatures on August 3 included 115 degrees at Ajo (record), 109 at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, 108 at Sells, and 104 at Picacho. On August 4 highs included 115 degrees at Ajo (tie), 110 at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, 109 at Sells (record), and 107 at Picacho. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one person found in the desert near San Miguel.

The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two males found in the desert in Pima County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot high temperatures of 101 to 107 degrees, or 8 to 12 degrees above normal, occurred in the lower elevations of Graham and eastern sections of Pinal and Pima counties on August 4, and caused the High Heat Risk category to be reached. High temperatures included 107 degrees at Tucson International Airport, 102 at Safford Airport, and 101 at Green Valley, San Manuel and Duncan. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one person found in the desert near Three Points.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures around 100 degrees in southern Cochise County were experienced on July 6. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two males found in the desert.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures 5 to 10 degrees above normal near 100 degrees, occurred in southern Cochise County causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached on July 10. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one male found in the desert near Palominas and another in the Leslie Canyon area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures of 100 to 105 degrees on the Tohono O'odham Nation were experienced on July 21. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one male found in the desert near Ali Chugk and a contributing factor of another male found near Vamori.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures 5 to 9 degrees above normal of 100 to 105 degrees, occurred on the Tohono O'odham Nation causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached on July 21. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one male found in the desert near Ali Chugk and a contributing factor to one male found near Vamori.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced in the lower elevations of southeast Arizona August 25 through 27, with high temperatures equaling or exceeding established records in a few locations, and approaching record levels in most others. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one male found in the desert.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot high temperatures of 104 to 114 degrees, or 5 to 11 degrees above normal, occurred in the lower elevations of Pima, southeast Pinal, and northwest sections of Cochise and Graham counties August 25-27 and caused the High Heat Risk category to be reached. The highest temperatures at select locations during the period were 114 degrees (tied record on 8/27) at Ajo, 112 (both records on 8/26 and 8/27) at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, 111 (record on 8/26) at Sells, 108 (one degree shy of the record on 8/27) at Picacho, 106 on 8/26 at Tucson International Airport, 105 on 8/25 and 8/26 at San Carlos and 103 on 8/25 at Cascabel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures around 105 degrees on the Tohono O'odham Nation and 110 in western Pima County were experienced on July 6.  The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for four males found in the desert.

The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three males found in the desert, two near Sells and one near Vamori.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced in much of southeast Arizona on August 3 and 4 with high temperatures equaling or exceeding established records in a few locations, and approaching record levels in most others. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two males found in the desert in Pima County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot high temperatures of 104 to 115 degrees, or 8 to 12 degrees above normal, occurred in the lower deserts of Pima and Pinal counties August 3-4, and caused the High Heat Risk category to be reached. High temperatures on August 3 included 115 degrees at Ajo (record), 109 at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, 108 at Sells, and 104 at Picacho. On August 4 highs included 115 degrees at Ajo (tie), 110 at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, 109 at Sells (record), and 107 at Picacho. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one person found in the desert near San Miguel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of high pressure centered over the Great Basin migrated east over the Four Corners region, allowing for temperatures to warm up above 110 degrees on the 9th. The official high temperature in Phoenix on the 9th topped out at 111 degrees. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 4 heat-associated fatalities occurred between the 9th and 10th.

A strong ridge of high pressure over the Desert Southwest resulted in excessive heat conditions as temperatures climbed well above normal. The hottest day in Phoenix occurred on the 4th with a high of 115 degrees. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 25 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two fatalities (1 direct and 1 indirect) were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

A broad upper level ridge over the Desert Southwest led to continued above normal temperatures along with excessive heat conditions for the middle part of September. Temperatures most afternoons during this time in Phoenix topped out around 108-109 degrees. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 10 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time. One of these fatalities included a person who died while hiking in Scottsdale. According to local media reports, a couple from Rhode Island started hiking around noon on the 12th at Brown's Ranch Trailhead in Scottsdale. After splitting up during the hike, the wife never returned to their meeting location. Local authorities responded and discovered that the wife had succumbed to the heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A couple from Rhode Island started hiking around noon on the 12th at Brown's Ranch Trailhead in Scottsdale. After splitting up during the hike, the wife never returned to their meeting location. Local authorities from various agencies responded to search for the missing woman. Shortly after 2100MST, local authorities found the missing woman who had succumbed to the heat.

An upper level ridge situated over much of the western United States at the end of July led to heat that resulted in several fatalities. One of these fatalities included a woman visiting from Boston who died after becoming overheated while hiking on Camelback Mountain. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, a total of 7 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two indirect fatalities were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over the Desert Southwest in early May allowed for temperatures to climb to around 100, which is about 10 degrees above normal for this time of the year. Phoenix officially hit 100 for the first time in 2021 on the 5th with temperatures peaking at 100 again on the 6th. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, two heat-associated fatalities occurred during this event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One direct fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over the Southwest allowed for temperatures across the Phoenix area to warm up above 100, which is about 7-10 degrees above normal for this time of the year. On the 13th, Phoenix officially hit 102, making it the warmest temperature recorded up to this point in the year and the warmest temperature during the month. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, five heat-associated fatalities occurred during this event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One direct fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender and circumstances unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An amplified upper level ridge situated over the West Coast allowed for temperatures to warm up above normal and even briefly reach excessive heat conditions across parts of the lower deserts. High temperatures in Phoenix during this time peaked on the 27th at 113 degrees, while low temperatures only fell into the low to mid 80s each night. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 17 fatalities occurred due to the heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three indirect fatalities were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level ridge strengthened over the Desert Southwest during the middle part of June with the center of high pressure becoming focused over the Four Corners region. As a result, temperatures warmed up well above normal reaching excessive heat conditions. High temperatures climbed at or above 115 degrees each day (6 days) between the 15th-20th, breaking Phoenix's record for consecutive days of 115+ degree temperatures. Temperatures in Phoenix peaked on the 17th at 118 degrees, breaking the record for the date and becoming the hottest temperature for the whole year. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, sixty heat-associated fatalities occurred as a result of this heat wave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An amplified upper level ridge situated over the West Coast allowed for temperatures to warm up above normal and even briefly reach excessive heat conditions across parts of the lower deserts. High temperatures in Phoenix during this time peaked on the 27th at 113 degrees, while low temperatures only fell into the low to mid 80s each night. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 17 fatalities occurred due to the heat.

A strong upper level ridge strengthened over the Desert Southwest during the middle part of June with the center of high pressure becoming focused over the Four Corners region. As a result, temperatures warmed up well above normal reaching excessive heat conditions. High temperatures climbed at or above 115 degrees each day (6 days) between the 15th-20th, breaking Phoenix's record for consecutive days of 115+ degree temperatures. Temperatures in Phoenix peaked on the 17th at 118 degrees, breaking the record for the date and becoming the hottest temperature for the whole year. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, sixty heat-associated fatalities occurred as a result of this heat wave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four fatalities (3 direct and 1 indirect) were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.
